Asked 10 People To Imagine Life After The Pandemic. Here's What They Said","subhead":null,"publishDate":"2021-03-17 05:01:25","updatedDate":"","relativeURL":"\u002Fcognoscenti\u002F2021\u002F03\u002F17\u002Fimagining-life-after-the-covid-19-pandemic","apiURL":"http:\u002F\u002Fapi.wbur.org\u002Fstories?date=2021-03-17&slug=imagining-life-after-the-covid-19-pandemic&sources=cognoscenti","externalURL":"","shortLink":"https:\u002F\u002Fwbur.fm\u002F3cETwlv","miniExcerpt":"","excerpt":"Nobody knows exactly what the world will look like after COVID. Uncertainty continues to reign. But for the first time in a long time, it feels like we can reasonably contemplate the future.","bylines":[{"name":"Cloe Axelson","nameLastFirst":"Axelson, Cloe","slug":"cloe-axelson","wordpressID":433,"content":["\u003Cstrong\u003ECloe Axelson\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E is an editor of WBUR’s opinion page, \u003Cem\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.wbur.org\u002Fcognoscenti\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003ECognoscenti\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fem\u003E. She previously worked for several nonprofit organizations, most recently as the director of communications for City Year and Match Education. She’s also worked as a speechwriter at the Democratic National Committee, a ghostwriter for a best-selling self-help author and as a grassroots organizer on political campaigns. Cloe has a M.S. in communication from Boston University and a B.A. in political science from Tufts University. She lives with her husband and their three young daughters near Boston."],"apiURL":"http:\u002F\u002Fapi.wbur.org\u002Fpeople\u002Fcloe-axelson","relativeURL":"\u002Finside\u002Fstaff\u002Fcloe-axelson","organization":"wbur","embedMeta":null,"shortBio":"Cloe Axelson is an editor of WBUR’s opinion page, Cognoscenti. ","twitter":"cloeax","facebook":null,"title":"Editor, Cognoscenti","type":"newsroom","channels":["cognoscenti","news"],"photo":"https:\u002F\u002Fd279m997dpfwgl.cloudfront.net\u002Fwp\u002F2013\u002F05\u002FCloe-Axelson.jpg","website":null,"email":null}],"nprID":null,"nprTranscriptID":null,"nprURL":null,"dateline":"","superTitle":"Commentary ","superTitleURL":null,"content":["As more and more people get vaccinated, the number of COVID-19 infections and deaths are finally declining. We know this pandemic won’t last forever.","But &mdash; what happens next? Do we just pick up where we left off in March 2020? Or have things changed in a fundamental way?","We asked 10 people to imagine life after the pandemic.","\u003Cspan data-index=\"1\" data-type=\"caption\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","What will work look like after COVID? What about parenting? Friendship? Faith? Will our understanding of public health change, as epidemiologists race to get ahead of the next pandemic?","The truth is, nobody knows exactly what comes next. Uncertainty continues to reign. But for the first time in a long time, it feels like we can reasonably contemplate the future &mdash; we are no longer locked in the “perpetual present.”","____","Read through each contributor's short essay below, or jump around to different topics using this navigation:","\u003Cul\u003E \t\u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca name=\"nav\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Ca href=\"#friendship\"\u003EFriendship | Joanna Weiss\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E \t\u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca name=\"nav\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Ca href=\"#health\"\u003EHealth | Sandro Galea\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E \t\u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca name=\"nav\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Ca href=\"#aging\"\u003EAging | Julie Wittes Schlack\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E \t\u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca name=\"nav\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Ca href=\"#parenting\"\u003EParenting | Sara Petersen\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E \t\u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca name=\"nav\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Ca href=\"#faith\"\u003EFaith | Taymullah Abdur-Rahman\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E \t\u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca name=\"nav\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Ca href=\"#education\"\u003EEducation | Neema Avashia\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E \t\u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca name=\"nav\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Ca href=\"#work\"\u003EWork | Julie Morgenstern\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E \t\u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca name=\"nav\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Ca href=\"#community\"\u003ECommunity | Roseann Bongiovanni\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E \t\u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca name=\"nav\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Ca href=\"#creativity\"\u003ECreativity | Desmond Hall\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E \t\u003Cli\u003E\u003Ca name=\"nav\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Ca href=\"#climate\"\u003EClimate | Philip Warburg\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\u003C\u002Ful\u003E","____","\u003Ca name=\"friendship\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E","\u003Ch2\u003EI’m Ready To Double Down On The Joys Of Physical Friendship\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E","\u003Cspan data-index=\"2\" data-type=\"caption\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","In the beginning, we had Zoom, and it was fine: virtual happy hours and online game nights that kept friendships alive when we had to be physically apart. But the pandemic separation couldn’t last.","In late spring, I took my first illicit walk with friends; we wore masks and glanced sideways to see if we’d be shamed. By summer, we were venting our frustrations during walks around a pond, holding birthday dinners outdoors, taking socially-distanced selfies with the timers on our phones. When winter came, we layered up like ice fishermen and huddled around fire pits on 30-degree nights.","\u003Cspan data-index=\"3\" data-type=\"pullquote\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","We’ve needed each other, and that’s good to know. One of the hardest things about COVID has been the way it rendered friendship dangerous &mdash; so many transmissions springing from in-person gatherings, as friends came together despite the directives. You can condemn all of those people as cavalier about public health. Or you could see their lapses as a feature of humanity.","\u003Cspan data-index=\"4\" data-type=\"caption\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","We’ve learned, this past year, that connection isn’t the same when it’s remote. And while many of us have broken the rules at least once or twice, we should acknowledge the lengths we’ve gone to see each other in relative safety.","When the COVID threat is gone, I predict that we’ll double down on the joys of physical friendship. I want to live dangerously with my besties. I want to double-dip in the guacamole. I want to sip your cocktail to see if I like it, too. I want to scream together into a karaoke microphone. I’ll pick the first song: “With a Little Help From My Friends.” --\u003Cstrong\u003E \u003Cem\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wbur.org\u002Finside\u002Fstaff\u002Fjoanna-weiss\"\u003EJoanna Weiss\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, \u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003Cem\u003EEditor, Northeastern University's \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fexpmag.com\u002F\"\u003EExperience\u003C\u002Fa\u003E magazine\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E","____","\u003Ca name=\"health\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E","\u003Ch2\u003EWe Need To Think About 'Health' In A New Way\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E","\u003Cspan data-index=\"5\" data-type=\"caption\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","In some ways, COVID-19 will be remembered as a triumph of biomedical science. We developed safe and effective vaccines &mdash; something that usually takes a decade or more &mdash; in less than a year. And, despite a number of stumbles, improved therapeutics reduced mortality from the virus in hospitals more than fourfold in a matter of months.","But COVID-19 provided, even more memorably, a terrifying and revealing view of our failure to create a world that generates health.","Once this pandemic ends, we’ll undoubtedly be having more conversations about how to prevent \u003Cem\u003Efuture \u003C\u002Fem\u003Epandemics, and ensure a healthier future. But will we be thinking about health in a bigger sense?","\u003Cspan data-index=\"6\" data-type=\"pullquote\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","Fundamentally, health is\u003Cem\u003E not \u003C\u002Fem\u003Ehealth care. Decades of underinvestment in healthy environments, adequate education, safe workspaces and livable wages resulted in a country that was unhealthy and vulnerable to the ravages of a novel virus. The U.S. has had the highest per capita rate of COVID-19 infections throughout the pandemic.","This moment should teach us that avoiding the next pandemic will require us to rethink how we approach health, so there are no \u003Cem\u003Ehaves \u003C\u002Fem\u003Eand \u003Cem\u003Ehave nots. \u003C\u002Fem\u003EIt’s recognition that we cannot be healthy, unless we build a world with safe housing, good schools, livable wages, gender and racial equity, clean air, drinkable water, a fair economy.","It’s time to change how we think about health. \u003Cem\u003E--\u003Cstrong\u003E \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wbur.org\u002Finside\u002Fstaff\u002Fsandro-galea\"\u003ESandro Galea\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EDean, Boston University, School Of Public Health\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fem\u003E","____","\u003Ca name=\"aging\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E","\u003Ch2\u003EThe Pandemic Deepened The Lessons Of Aging\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E","\u003Cspan data-index=\"7\" data-type=\"caption\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","My husband and I are in our late 60s. Fed, housed, and able to freelance, we’ve weathered the past year with gratitude and relative ease. But like many of our peers, the pandemic has intensified our feelings about how we want to live the rest of our lives, in intentional community. Our choices feel quite personal, but they are representative of emerging trends.","\u003Cspan data-index=\"8\" data-type=\"caption\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","In a post-pandemic future, we can expect to see the biggest change in where and with whom the elderly live. With 40% of all fatalities, the virus’s impact on residents of nursing homes has been earth-shaking, fueling people’s desire to age in place or live in settings where mutual aid is the norm. Stunned by the isolation of the pandemic, most of the new recruits to our co-housing community have been people over 60. Local programs supporting in-home care are on the rise, and \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wsj.com\u002Farticles\u002Fhow-covid-19-will-change-aging-and-retirement-11605452401\"\u003Estate and federal programs paying family caregivers\u003C\u002Fa\u003E are also likely to expand.","Technological advances will also pave the way for aging in place. Telehealth is more widely accepted, and devices like smart speakers will soon notify loved ones if you call out for help. Indeed, the pandemic has highlighted our intergenerational interdependence. With schools and daycares closed, working parents have moved in with their parents so that they can help mind the kids, and many adult children, having been deprived of the ability to see their quarantined loved ones, are determined to pre-empt that scenario in the future.","\u003Cspan data-index=\"9\" data-type=\"pullquote\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","Will market volatility make it less likely that people will retire? Or will the COVID-induced knowledge of our own vulnerability fuel our urgency to pursue what we value versus what we’re paid for? I don’t know. But I do know that COVID has deepened the lessons that aging inevitably bestows: Don’t take your family and friends for granted. Protect your health. Accept that you’re going to die and live accordingly. --\u003Cstrong\u003E \u003Cem\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wbur.org\u002Finside\u002Fstaff\u002Fjulie-wittes-schlack\"\u003EJulie Wittes Schlack\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, Writer\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E","____","\u003Ca name=\"parenting\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E","\u003Ch2\u003EMothers Continue To Hold Up A Broken System\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E","\u003Cspan data-index=\"10\" data-type=\"caption\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","I never harbored any illusions about living in a culture that values mothers. From day one, my experience as a mom has been peppered with moments of rage and periods of existential crisis. I love the \u003Cem\u003Elove\u003C\u002Fem\u003E of motherhood, but the work of mothering is mostly unsupported and un-respected. The nonstop parenting, teaching, cooking, cleaning that mothering has entailed during the pandemic has confirmed that this type of labor is also, for me, largely a drag.","Although the beauty of motherhood is widely celebrated on Instagram and elsewhere, our primary value lies in our ability to raise the next generation of workers and consumers. As the pandemic has shown, mothers’ needs don’t really seem to matter. Our needs don’t impact the bottom line.","\u003Cspan data-index=\"11\" data-type=\"pullquote\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","The pandemic calcified my fury that mothers are expected to hold up the whole of a very broken system, while being given nothing in return. In the past year, we’ve seen a flurry of essays and reporting showing that women and mothers have been disproportionately burdened with the impossible task of keeping society afloat (the latest New York Times series is appropriately titled, “\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002Finteractive\u002F2021\u002F02\u002F04\u002Fparenting\u002Fworking-moms-coronavirus.html\"\u003EThe Primal Scream\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.”) The coverage is affirming and necessary, but not a single mother I know has been surprised about any of the awful statistics or heartbreaking personal stories.","When this is over, I’m looking forward to no longer being the sole provider of all things to my kids. But I also wonder if the tidal wave of momentum inspired by the pandemic will carry us through to something better than think-pieces.","\u003Cspan data-index=\"12\" data-type=\"twitter\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","We need equal and fair pay for mothers. We need humane prenatal and postnatal care, and paid parental leave legislation. We need to reform our racist health care system that has led to countless Black mothers’ deaths. We need to end the debate on whether women’s reproductive rights are actual rights. And we need to radically rethink our capitalist system, which uses mothers and other care workers to uphold the primary concerns of buying and selling, while denying them adequate compensation &mdash; or even cultural respect for their indispensable work.","I wonder if women’s rage will coalesce into action. I hope so. -- \u003Cem\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wbur.org\u002Finside\u002Fstaff\u002Fsara-petersen\"\u003ESara Petersen\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, Writer\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E \u003C\u002Fem\u003E","____","\u003Ca name=\"faith\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E","\u003Ch2\u003EThe Pandemic Forced Us To Take Faith Into Our Own Hands\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E","\u003Cspan data-index=\"13\" data-type=\"caption\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","I spent many nights in the last year contemplating God’s wisdom and purpose, while fielding the despair and weariness of many Muslims who sought my counsel. They wanted to know, was COVID a pandemic or the plague, and what was the difference? Was it God’s wrath or God’s cleansing? Was there a collective spiritual remedy to make it all go away?","As we begin to see a light at the end of the tunnel, I wonder if and how our faith as Americans has changed.","It was no coincidence that the height of the pandemic in Massachusetts last spring struck during the Holy days of all three Abrahamic faiths. Easter, Passover and Ramadan came and went in our homes. We had to learn to celebrate without the pomp of public worship. People who attended church, temple and mosque &mdash; but never took it upon themselves to utter their own personal prayers &mdash; were forced to petition God themselves.","\u003Cspan data-index=\"14\" data-type=\"pullquote\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","I watched my own teenage children reluctantly read the Quran aloud at home for the Eid Holidays (without the help of the entire mosque). As life returns to normal, I suspect we’ll have a deeper appreciation for our respective worship-communities and the spaces of comfort they provide us.","I also think the goals of the American faithful have shifted slightly. We want a little less of the world now, and more authentic connections with real people. God forced us to stop our schedules to give us a moment to take faith into our own hands &mdash; and for the most part we did.","Now I believe God will allow us to embrace one another again, both literally and figuratively. -- \u003Cem\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wbur.org\u002Finside\u002Fstaff\u002Ftaymullah-abdur-rahman\"\u003ETaymullah Abdul-Rahman\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, Imam, Massachusetts Department of Correction\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fem\u003E","____","\u003Ca name=\"education\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E","\u003Ch2\u003EI Worry Education In A Post-COVID World Won't Change Enough\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E","\u003Cspan data-index=\"15\" data-type=\"caption\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","My greatest fear is that K-12 education in a post-COVID world will not change enough. As an 8th grade teacher, the past 12 months have completely changed how I approach my work.","In-person, Ms. Avashia was all about urgency and rigor and content, content, content. Pandemic-teaching Ms. Avashia moves much more slowly with her students.","\u003Cspan data-index=\"16\" data-type=\"twitter\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","Now, I focus my efforts on deep learning, instead of coverage of pages of standards. Each day, we work through one meaningful task, instead of trying to speed through three or four. We \u003Cem\u003Eplay \u003C\u002Fem\u003Emore in class &mdash; using riddles or visual puzzles, telling jokes in the chat, changing our Zoom profile pictures, to make each other laugh. I’ve even dressed up in costumes multiple times this year just to bring kids some moments of humor.","Teaching during the pandemic has pushed me to be so much more human with my students, and to teach into their humanity. And that, at its core, is completely different from how education has traditionally been structured in our society.","I believe deeply in the democratic cornerstone of public education. But we have never succeeded in fulfilling its promise for all of our students, particularly those students most impacted by racial and economic injustice in our country.","\u003Cspan data-index=\"17\" data-type=\"caption\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","Our school buildings have been sites of over-policing of students’ bodies, of adultifying and criminalizing adolescent behavior, of reducing student learning down to what can be demonstrated on standardized tests.","We have an opportunity to walk away from those practices forever. To build educational settings that are grounded in students’ humanity, and designed with their voices, needs and interests at the center. To ensure that our schools are structured and staffed to prioritize relationship-building, robust mental health services and targeted academic supports. We can affirm the notion that schools are cornerstones of both our democracy and our communities, by fully funding the work that we as a society are asking them to do.","\u003Cspan data-index=\"18\" data-type=\"pullquote\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","We can do all of this. We should do all of this. The question is: Will we? -- \u003Cem\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wbur.org\u002Finside\u002Fstaff\u002Fneema-avashia\"\u003ENeema Avashia\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, Teacher, McCormack Middle School\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fem\u003E","____","\u003Ca name=\"work\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E","\u003Ch2\u003ECOVID Forced Companies To Be More Flexible. Will They Harness The Lessons Learned?\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E","\u003Cspan data-index=\"19\" data-type=\"caption\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","The “culture of time” at many companies wasn’t healthy before the pandemic. Some organizations were trying to address bad habits (no time to think, everything-gets-done-by-meetings culture), before new problems like Zoom fatigue and FOLO (Fear Of Logging Off) took hold.","The pandemic accelerated a comeuppance about how the workplace can and should evolve. I think the lessons we learned this year will almost certainly lead to greater flexibility in the long term.","This year proved that a lot of work can be done remotely. It also made clear the handful of things better done in person &mdash; bonding, mentoring and new relationship building. Companies will need to bring people together regularly to ensure the kismet that happens in 3D.","\u003Cspan data-index=\"20\" data-type=\"pullquote\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","Every worker needs time and space for quiet work, time and space for meetings, and time and space for informal and more casual communication. This was true pre-pandemic, and it’s still true. Future workspaces are likely to reflect these needs: large library-like areas where people can go to do their thinking (like the quiet car on a train); lots of formal and informal meeting areas; and administrative spaces to deal with email and chat with coworkers.","Back-to-back meetings &mdash; 7 to 10 Zooms a day &mdash; is not an effective way to work. It leaves no time to think, or to actually do the work generated in those meetings.","Companies seem to have finally learned that their employees are whole people. Work is part of their lives, and their lives beyond work are essential and valuable to their well-being. In our post-COVID world, I suspect the role of chief people officer and chief wellness officer will evolve, and be seen as a critical role for a healthy organization.","COVID forced organizations to change. It forced them to be more flexible, and that experience highlighted what went missing in a 100% remote environment. The job of leaders is now to stop, reflect and embrace what we discovered in the last year, and consciously build workplaces and workspaces that harness those lessons, to enable companies to achieve their goals and workers to feel fulfilled. --\u003Cem\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wbur.org\u002Finside\u002Fstaff\u002Fjulie-morgenstern\"\u003EJulie Morgenstern\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.juliemorgenstern.com\u002F\"\u003EProductivity Expert\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, Author\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fem\u003E","____","\u003Ca name=\"community\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E","\u003Ch2\u003EWe Must Do Right By The Communities, Including Chelsea, That Suffered The Most\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E","\u003Cspan data-index=\"21\" data-type=\"caption\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","I’ve lived in Chelsea my whole life, but I don’t remember my community ever being in the news as much as it was during the first peak of the pandemic. With the highest infection rate in Massachusetts &mdash; and blocks’ long lines of people waiting for food &mdash; Chelsea was on display for the world to see. Even my family in Argentina saw news reports of our city being slammed by the raging pandemic.","During those difficult days, people opened up their hearts for the residents of our community. Those of us involved in addressing the coronavirus pandemic in Chelsea, received an outpouring of support through donations, volunteering, well wishes and prayers for recovery and hope.","Other low-income, ethnically and racially diverse communities like Chelsea faced the same wrath. Years of structural oppression and racism leading to health, environmental and economic disparities, have made the effects of COVID-19 so much more pronounced.","My post-pandemic hope is that the hearts and minds of those outside of these cities remember how much communities like \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wbur.org\u002Fcognoscenti\u002F2020\u002F05\u002F05\u002Fchelsea-coronavirus-roseann-bongiovanni-leslie-dominguez-santos\"\u003EChelsea\u003C\u002Fa\u003E have sacrificed. Will you remember us in six months? Six years? Sixteen years from now?","\u003Cspan data-index=\"22\" data-type=\"pullquote\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","Will the people of Massachusetts continue to have communities like Chelsea in their hearts and minds? Will you reflect on our disproportionate environmental and industrial burdens, poor public transportation, food insecurity, housing instability and low wages for essential workers? Will others say, “We can shoulder a little bit of the burden, so it’s not all on the backs of low-income communities of color?”","We must learn from the past year, and from the reasons for Chelsea’s soaring infection rates. We must pass laws to protect environmental justice communities. We must say “no” to new toxic facilities. We must prioritize the health and well-being of all people, but particularly those who have faced oppression, discrimination and racism, which caused these health disparities. --\u003Cstrong\u003E \u003Cem\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wbur.org\u002Finside\u002Fstaff\u002Froseann-bongiovanni\"\u003ERoseann Bongiovanni\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, Executive Director, \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.greenrootschelsea.org\u002F\"\u003EGreenRoots\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E","____","\u003Ca name=\"creativity\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E","\u003Ch2\u003EWill Art Remain The Unifying Force It’s Always Been?\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E","\u003Cspan data-index=\"23\" data-type=\"caption\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","I’m sitting behind my screen, fractured from the world.","I don’t feel the need to see other people as much as I did earlier in the pandemic. Has something happened to me on a molecular level? Is the isolation hitting other writers and artists the way it’s hitting me?","We already live in a world of separate platforms. News broadcasts spin the same events in different ways for different people. The platforms dictate what we see based on what the platforms think we want to see. They strut the arrogance of knowing us better than we do. And now the pandemic has further alienated all of us.","\u003Cspan data-index=\"24\" data-type=\"pullquote\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","This worries me, because I love when artists create the specific that’s felt universally. I wrote a book about a \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.simonandschuster.com\u002Fbooks\u002FYour-Corner-Dark\u002FDesmond-Hall\u002F9781534460713\"\u003Eboy and his family in rural Jamaica\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. So far it has resonated in other parts of the world. But if we continue to be so isolated will we be too separated to partake in varied experiences?","It was only a short while ago when some Hollywood execs deemed a movie like “Black Panther” was \u003Cem\u003Etoo ethnic\u003C\u002Fem\u003E to have widespread appeal. They doubted that the specific had universality. The film proved them wrong, but what if we continue to grow apart, divided? Will some art be discarded as irrelevant because large swaths of people can’t relate, can’t see the universality?","I believe in art as a unifying force, as a medium that reveals our commonalities and reasons to strive together. I hope the isolation we’ve endured this year won’t stunt our ability to connect to each other. -- \u003Cem\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wbur.org\u002Finside\u002Fstaff\u002Fdesmond-hall\"\u003EDesmond Hall\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, Author, Visual Artist\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E \u003C\u002Fem\u003E","____","\u003Ca name=\"climate\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E","\u003Ch2\u003EBehavior Change Won't Be Enough To Avert Climate Catastrophe\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E","\u003Cspan data-index=\"25\" data-type=\"caption\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","With more than half a million lives lost in the U.S., the COVID crisis has yielded a sobering lesson about human resistance to change, even in the face of devastating consequences.","Wearing masks in public? A no-brainer. Avoiding large indoor gatherings? Ditto. Yet when official directives and common sense have impinged on individual choice, too often they have collided with indifference, indignation and defiance.","Some wonder if there are lessons to be learned from the pandemic as we seek to avert the worst ravages of climate change. With many working remotely rather than traveling daily to their offices, reduced commuting has doubtless contributed to \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2021\u002F01\u002F12\u002Fclimate\u002F2020-greenhouse-gas-emissions.html\"\u003Ethe past year’s drop of more than 10%\u003C\u002Fa\u003E in U.S. greenhouse gas emissions. It’s a pretty sure bet, though, that commuters will refill our highways, with more people than ever traveling by car for fear of infection on public transit.","Air travel, too, is likely to rebound as business trips come back into vogue and leisure travelers take to the skies.","\u003Cspan data-index=\"26\" data-type=\"pullquote\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","Rather than placing our bets on behavioral change, we need to demand of government and industry what we cannot expect of ourselves. All levels of government must require a true gearing-up of renewable energy as our primary electricity source.","In addition, the federal government must mandate a shift to \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wbur.org\u002Fcognoscenti\u002F2021\u002F02\u002F01\u002Fbiden-climate-change-federal-electric-fleet-gm-philip-warburg\"\u003Ecleaner, leaner motor vehicles\u003C\u002Fa\u003E &mdash; a challenge bigger than simply electrifying the behemoths that now roll off our production lines. And governing bodies at all levels must embrace an unprecedented commitment to energy justice, making it possible for low-income people to make their homes more efficient, buy energy-efficient appliances, and install solar power on their rooftops and in their communities.","It would be folly to rely on new patterns of human behavior emerging from the COVID catastrophe to address climate change. We need to make an all-out investment in retooling the engines of our society. --\u003Cstrong\u003E \u003Cem\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wbur.org\u002Finside\u002Fstaff\u002Fphilip-warburg\"\u003EPhilip Warburg\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, Senior Fellow, Boston University Institute Of Sustainable Energy\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E","____","\u003Cem\u003EAmy Gorel, Lisa Creamer and Kathleen Burge helped with the production of this piece. The audio essay was was produced by Cloe Axelson, with help from David Greene; it was mixed by Michael Garth. \u003C\u002Fem\u003E","\u003Cem\u003EFollow Cognoscenti on \u003Ca Nott for WBUR)","alt":"(Dan Nott for WBUR)"},"body":"\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fd279m997dpfwgl.cloudfront.net\u002Fwp\u002F2021\u002F03\u002FAfter-Covid-Spot-Education-1.jpg\"\u003E\u003Cimg affirm the notion that schools are cornerstones of both our democracy and our communities...","placeholder":"\u003Cspan data-index=\"18\" Walker\u002FThe Boston Globe via Getty Images)","alt":""},"body":"\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fd279m997dpfwgl.cloudfront.net\u002Fwp\u002F2021\u002F03\u002FGettyImages-1209894633.jpg\"\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"size-full wp-image-668281\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fd279m997dpfwgl.cloudfront.net\u002Fwp\u002F2021\u002F03\u002FGettyImages-1209894633.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1024\" height=\"683\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E","placeholder":"\u003Cspan data-index=\"19\" data-type=\"caption\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E"},"embed-20":{"id":20,"parentID":667043,"type":"pullquote","attributes":{"author":"Julie Morgenstern, Author, Productivity Expert"},"body":"The pandemic accelerated a comeuppance about how the workplace can and should evolve. ","placeholder":"\u003Cspan data-index=\"20\" data-type=\"pullquote\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E"},"embed-21":{"id":21,"parentID":667043,"type":"caption","attributes":{"id":"attachment_578598","align":"aligncenter","width":"3000","caption":"Chelsea residents stand in a line at a pop-up food pantry in Washington Park. (Jesse Costa\u002FWBUR)"},"body":"\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fd279m997dpfwgl.cloudfront.net\u002Fwp\u002F2020\u002F03\u002F0422_natl-guard-food-distribution13.jpg\"\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"size-full wp-image-578598\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fd279m997dpfwgl.cloudfront.net\u002Fwp\u002F2020\u002F03\u002F0422_natl-guard-food-distribution13.jpg\" alt=\"At a pop-up food pantry at Washington Park, Chelsea residents stand in a line that extends through the middle and around the perimeter of the park. (Jesse Costa\u002FWBUR)\" width=\"3000\" height=\"2000\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E","placeholder":"\u003Cspan data-index=\"21\" data-type=\"caption\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E"},"embed-22":{"id":22,"parentID":667043,"type":"pullquote","attributes":{"author":"Roseann Bongiovanni, Executive Director, GreenRoots"},"body":"Will the people of Massachusetts continue to have communities like Chelsea in their hearts and minds?","placeholder":"\u003Cspan data-index=\"22\" data-type=\"pullquote\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E"},"embed-23":{"id":23,"parentID":667043,"type":"caption","attributes":{"id":"attachment_192409","align":"alignnone","width":"1700","caption":"Artist Silvia López Chavez applies an anti-graffiti solution to her mural on the Esplanade's Dr. Paul Dudley White Bike Path. (Jesse Costa\u002FWBUR)","alt":"Artist Silvia LÃ³pez Chavez applies an anti-graffiti solution to her mural on the Esplanade's Dr. Paul Dudley White Bike Path. 04:58:08","updated_at":"2016-06-08 04:58:08","minimumItems":4,"maximumItems":4,"itemMultiplier":null,"isContentTarget":true,"title":"Features","type":"stories","supportsAd":true,"supportsRelLinks":false,"supportsSectionBar":true,"requiresImage":false,"fullContent":false},"contentItems":[{"slug":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.npr.org\u002F2021\u002F03\u002F20\u002F979542001\u002Fwe-will-not-go-back-vigils-honoring-atlanta-victims-draw-mourners-across-u-s","program":null,"images":[{"id":"979546382","title":"A Tuesday's shootings in Atlanta at a vigil in New York City, one of many across the country this week. (Stephanie Keith\u002FGetty Images)","credit":"Getty Images","url":"https:\u002F\u002Fmedia.npr.org\u002Fassets\u002Fimg\u002F2021\u002F03\u002F20\u002Fnyc-atlanta-vigil-e793d5ddc911bb33568ff59caa017dfb98409364.jpg","sizes":{"thumb":{"width":0,"height":0,"file":"https:\u002F\u002Fmedia.npr.org\u002Fassets\u002Fimg\u002F2021\u002F03\u002F20\u002Fnyc-atlanta-vigil-e793d5ddc911bb33568ff59caa017dfb98409364.jpg?s=12","type":"thumb"},"medium":{"width":0,"height":0,"file":"https:\u002F\u002Fmedia.npr.org\u002Fassets\u002Fimg\u002F2021\u002F03\u002F20\u002Fnyc-atlanta-vigil-e793d5ddc911bb33568ff59caa017dfb98409364.jpg?s=4","type":"medium"},"large":{"width":0,"height":0,"file":"https:\u002F\u002Fmedia.npr.org\u002Fassets\u002Fimg\u002F2021\u002F03\u002F20\u002Fnyc-atlanta-vigil-e793d5ddc911bb33568ff59caa017dfb98409364.jpg?s=6","type":"large"},"full":{"width":0,"height":0,"file":"https:\u002F\u002Fmedia.npr.org\u002Fassets\u002Fimg\u002F2021\u002F03\u002F20\u002Fnyc-atlanta-vigil-e793d5ddc911bb33568ff59caa017dfb98409364.jpg","type":"full"},"square":{"width":0,"height":0,"file":"https:\u002F\u002Fmedia.npr.org\u002Fassets\u002Fimg\u002F2021\u002F03\u002F20\u002Fnyc-atlanta-vigil_sq-74f2d1f62de7aa9cfbe97160bec36188ea2f0720.jpg","type":"square"}}}],"content":["From Sacramento to Salt Lake City to Philadelphia, thousands gathered this weekend at vigils across the country with signs, candles, portraits and flowers grieving the eight victims of Tuesday's shootings in Atlanta and crying out against anti-Asian racism. ","In Atlanta, hundreds attended a rally and march Saturday afternoon, some holding signs reading \"Stop Asian Hate\" and \"Racism Is A Virus.\" The demonstrators met at Liberty Plaza, across the street from the Georgia state Capitol, where just last year lawmakers passed a hate crimes bill allowing additional penalties to be added when perpetrators are convicted of other crimes. ","The suspect in Tuesday's shootings, a 21-year-old white man, \u003Ca href=\"\u002F\u002Fwww.wbur.org\u002Fnpr\u002F978141138\u002Fatlanta-shooting-suspect-is-believed-to-have-visited-spas-he-targeted\"\u003Ehas been charged with eight counts of murder\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. Investigators say the suspect claims race did not play a role in targeting the businesses, but they have not yet ruled out a racist motive. ","\"I know there's a lot of fear in the Asian American community — fear to walk outside their door, fear to go to their businesses,\" said Georgia state Rep. Sam Park, the son of Korean immigrants who became the first Korean American Democrat elected to the Georgia state legislature in 2016. \"I want to tell anyone who may be scared today: Do not be afraid. This is our home. This is our country. And we will not go back.\"","Tuesday's killings came as many Asian Americans were already trying to draw attention to an increase in anti-Asian hate incidents and violence during the coronavirus pandemic. \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.csusb.edu\u002Fsites\u002Fdefault\u002Ffiles\u002FFACT%20SHEET-%20Anti-Asian%20Hate%202020%203.2.21.pdf\"\u003EA recent study from California State University-San Bernardino\u003C\u002Fa\u003E found anti-Asian hate crimes rose in several large cities in 2020. ","\u003Ca href=\"\u002F\u002Fwww.wbur.org\u002Fnpr\u002F979170481\u002Fbiden-and-harris-meeting-in-atlanta-with-asian-american-community-leaders\"\u003EPresident Biden spoke out against anti-Asian hate\u003C\u002Fa\u003E in an address from Atlanta Friday night, while a vigil in New York City drew Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer, New York Mayor Bill de Blasio and mayoral hopeful Andrew Yang. ","\u003Cfigure class=\"article-fig size-large\"\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"size-large article-image\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fmedia.npr.org\u002Fassets\u002Fimg\u002F2021\u002F03\u002F20\u002Fgold-spa-flowers-305618af13f5561f1e2cae7a4eb7e476d09f126c.jpg?s=6\"\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"article-fig-caption article-fig-caption--pull\"\u003EMourners during a quiet moment at Gold Spa, where dozens have left bouquets and candles in the days since Tuesday's shootings. (Megan Varner\u002FGetty Images)\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E","Speaking to the crowd of hundreds gathered in Manhattan's Union Square, New York state Sen. John Liu joined the many this week who have \u003Ca href=\"\u002F\u002Fwww.wbur.org\u002Fnpr\u002F978680316\u002Fatlanta-spa-shootings-expose-frustration-and-debate-over-hate-crime-label\"\u003Ecriticized authorities in Cherokee County, Ga.\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, for seemingly taking the shooter at his word in denying the attack was racially motivated. ","\"He had his gun and went into an Asian business looking to kill Asians, and then he did it again,\" said Liu, who is Taiwanese American. \"And there's a question as to whether this is a hate crime? That is absolutely outrageous.\"","For Asian American owners of businesses, the shootings left them newly worried about their own safety after a year \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.pewresearch.org\u002Fsocial-trends\u002F2020\u002F07\u002F01\u002Fmany-black-and-asian-americans-say-they-have-experienced-discrimination-amid-the-covid-19-outbreak\u002F\"\u003Emany say\u003C\u002Fa\u003E has been marked by racist comments about the coronavirus pandemic. ","At \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.facebook.com\u002Fwatch\u002Flive\u002F?v=480088573043881\"\u003Ea virtual vigil hosted Friday night\u003C\u002Fa\u003E by the Atlanta chapter of the National Asian Pacific American Women's Forum, Atlanta-area restaurant owner Ching Hsia said Tuesday's attack left her afraid for her family and their employees at Yen Jing, their Korean-Chinese restaurant in Doraville, Ga.","\"We receive racist calls asking if we sold bat soup, or if anyone working at the restaurant has coronavirus,\" Hsia said. \"We had customers who refused to wear a mask even when we offered them masks for free, saying things like 'Why should we be the one wearing masks when it was you who brought it over here?' \" ","\"Today it happened to massage parlors,\" she added. \"Tomorrow it could be restaurants, salons, anywhere else.\"  ","\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.npr.org\u002F2021\u002F03\u002F20\u002F979542001\u002Fwe-will-not-go-back-vigils-honoring-atlanta-victims-draw-mourners-across-u-s\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ECopyright NPR Will Not Go Back': Vigils Honoring Atlanta Victims Draw Mourners Across U.S.","publishDate":"2021-03-20 racism.","nprID":979542001,"nprURL":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.npr.org\u002F2021\u002F03\u002F20\u002F979542001\u002Fwe-will-not-go-back-vigils-honoring-atlanta-victims-draw-mourners-across-u-s","dateline":"","superTitleURL":"","postType":"","isBreaking":false,"isDeveloping":false,"relatedLinksLabel":"Related:","broadcastType":null,"broadcastDate":"","broadcastTime":"","itunesEpType":"","itunesEpNum":"","itunesTitle":"","itunesSummary":"","itunesExplicit":false,"volume":3,"disqus":null,"googlePick":false,"suppressAudio":false,"amp":false,"updateDate":"2021-03-20 16:02:00","taxonomy":[{"title":"Race","link":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.npr.org\u002Fsections\u002Frace\u002F","id":1015},{"title":"National","link":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.npr.org\u002Fsections\u002Fnational\u002F","id":1003},{"title":"News","link":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.npr.org\u002Fsections\u002Fnews\u002F","id":1001}],"embedMeta":null,"index":1,"editorCreated":true,"displayAsPullquote":false,"isAd":false,"videos":[]},{"slug":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.npr.org\u002F2021\u002F03\u002F20\u002F979596524\u002Funder-fire-the-ncaa-apologizes-and-unveils-new-weight-room-for-womens-tournament","program":null,"images":[{"id":"979604056","title":"The NCAA scrambled to unveil a new weight room for players in its women's basketball tournament after controversy erupted this week over disparities between the men's and women's events.","caption":"The NCAA scrambled to unveil a new weight room for players in its women's basketball tournament after controversy erupted this week over disparities between the men's and women's events. (Eric Gay\u002FAP)","credit":"AP","url":"https:\u002F\u002Fmedia.npr.org\u002Fassets\u002Fimg\u002F2021\u002F03\u002F20\u002Fncaa-womens-bball_wide-2b9ce6413dbbdbdf85c90683dc37b6fdc0d30b6c.jpg","sizes":{"thumb":{"width":0,"height":0,"file":"https:\u002F\u002Fmedia.npr.org\u002Fassets\u002Fimg\u002F2021\u002F03\u002F20\u002Fncaa-womens-bball_wide-2b9ce6413dbbdbdf85c90683dc37b6fdc0d30b6c.jpg?s=12","type":"thumb"},"medium":{"width":0,"height":0,"file":"https:\u002F\u002Fmedia.npr.org\u002Fassets\u002Fimg\u002F2021\u002F03\u002F20\u002Fncaa-womens-bball_wide-2b9ce6413dbbdbdf85c90683dc37b6fdc0d30b6c.jpg?s=4","type":"medium"},"large":{"width":0,"height":0,"file":"https:\u002F\u002Fmedia.npr.org\u002Fassets\u002Fimg\u002F2021\u002F03\u002F20\u002Fncaa-womens-bball_wide-2b9ce6413dbbdbdf85c90683dc37b6fdc0d30b6c.jpg?s=6","type":"large"},"full":{"width":0,"height":0,"file":"https:\u002F\u002Fmedia.npr.org\u002Fassets\u002Fimg\u002F2021\u002F03\u002F20\u002Fncaa-womens-bball_wide-2b9ce6413dbbdbdf85c90683dc37b6fdc0d30b6c.jpg","type":"full"},"square":{"width":0,"height":0,"file":"https:\u002F\u002Fmedia.npr.org\u002Fassets\u002Fimg\u002F2021\u002F03\u002F20\u002Fncaa-womens-bball_sq-2b511e1065cb8393dc50aa5e7f4aac0ff900b20d.jpg","type":"square"}}}],"content":["Under fire for differences in amenities for its men's and women's basketball tournaments, the NCAA revealed an upgraded weight room Saturday for players participating in the women's college basketball tournament in San Antonio.","What had been a single small rack of dumbbells has now been replaced with a larger space with more equipment, including a variety of bars, racks and stands.","The facilities were upgraded overnight after the organization was widely criticized by players, coaches and fans alike.","https:\u002F\u002Ftwitter.com\u002FCollegeGameDay\u002Fstatus\u002F1373305725708070918","\"I want to be really clear,'' NCAA President Mark Emmert said in an interview on Friday with reporters. \"This is not something that should have happened and, should we ever conduct a tournament like this again, will ever happen again.''","\u003Ca href=\"\u002F\u002Fwww.wbur.org\u002Fnpr\u002F979395795\u002Fmens-and-womens-ncaa-march-madness-facilities-separate-and-unequal-spark-uproar\"\u003EThe controversy broke Thursday\u003C\u002Fa\u003E after a coach from Stanford University posted a photo to social media comparing the men's and women's weight setups.","Responding to the controversy Friday, the NCAA's vice president of women's basketball, Lynn Holzman, acknowledged in a press briefing that the organization \"fell short.\" She added that the NCAA had originally intended for women to have access to a full weight room once their teams had reached the third round of the tournament. The men's teams have access to a full weight room during the entirety of their tournament runs.","The controversy picked up steam as more disparities were revealed: uninspiring box meals compared with a buffet with steak fillets and lobster mac 'n' cheese; swag bags appearing to be a third the size of the men's.","Perhaps most eye-opening, University of Connecticut coach Geno Auriemma told reporters Friday that the school's men's team was being tested daily with highly accurate PCR coronavirus tests, while his women's team was receiving antigen tests, which are less accurate. The NCAA later confirmed that the two tournaments are using different testing methods.","Reaction to the disparities was swift and negative. Joining the voices of female players facing the conditions in San Antonio were NBA stars like \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftwitter.com\u002FStephenCurry30\u002Fstatus\u002F1372792082058813443\"\u003ESteph Curry\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftwitter.com\u002FKyrieIrving\u002Fstatus\u002F1372968838510354435\"\u003EKyrie Irving\u003C\u002Fa\u003E alongside top college administrators and coaches.","\"I appreciate that [the NCAA] is working on a solution but this is unacceptable to begin with,\" \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftwitter.com\u002FRossBjorkAD\u002Fstatus\u002F1372721252406812679\"\u003Ewrote Ross Bjork\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, the athletics director at Texas A&M, on Twitter. \"No one in athletics would have thought this was appropriate if someone would have been consulted.\"","Others were less surprised by the discrepancies.","The fact that \"there's a huge disparity between men's and women's sports is hardly breaking news,\" \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftwitter.com\u002FMuffetMcGraw\u002Fstatus\u002F1373321930485473287\"\u003Esaid former longtime Notre Dame coach Muffet McGraw\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. \"The NCAA had an opportunity to highlight how sport can be a place where we don't just talk about equality we put it on display. To say they dropped the ball would be the understatement of the century.\"","Addressing the other apparent disparities Friday, NCAA officials said that despite appearances, the swag bags were equal in value and that the food quality had been \"addressed immediately\" with the hotels in San Antonio housing the women's teams.","As for the differences in testing, Emmert, the NCAA's president, said Friday that he had \"complete confidence\" in the different protocols, pointing to the organization's partnerships with local health organizations in Indianapolis and San Antonio.","\"All of the health experts say the protocol that they're using right now in all our venues and all our championships is one that has no difference at all in our ability to mitigate risk,\" he said.  ","\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.npr.org\u002F2021\u002F03\u002F20\u002F979596524\u002Funder-fire-the-ncaa-apologizes-and-unveils-new-weight-room-for-womens-tournament\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ECopyright NPR 2021.\u003Cimg src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.google-analytics.com\u002F__utm.gif?utmac=UA-5828686-4&utmdt=Under+Fire%2C+The+NCAA+Apologizes+And+Unveils+New+Weight+Room+For+Women%27s+Tournament&utme=8(APIKey)9(MDAyNzUwMDI2MDEyNTA3MTU5NzcyNTQyNA004)\"\u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E"],"nprTranscriptID":977797909,"audio":[],"relatedLinks":[],"superTitle":null,"bylines":[{"name":"Becky Sullivan","relativeURL":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.npr.org\u002Fpeople\u002F348743421\u002Fbecky-sullivan?ft=nprml&f=977797909,979542001,979596524","id":"348743421"}],"channel":"NPR","fullChannel":null,"channelType":"","channelURL":"","id":979596524,"wordpressSlug":"","wordpressID":null,"guid":"","source":"NPR","headline":"Under Fire, The NCAA Apologizes And Unveils New Weight Room For Women's Tournament","publishDate":"2021-03-20 00:00:00","updatedDate":"","relativeURL":"\u002Fnpr\u002F979596524\u002Funder-fire-the-ncaa-apologizes-and-unveils-new-weight-room-for-womens-tournament","apiURL":"http:\u002F\u002Fapi.wbur.org\u002Fstories?id=979596524&org=npr","externalURL":"","shortLink":"","miniExcerpt":"","excerpt":"Facing a mountain of criticism, the organization said it \"fell short\" as it raced to set up a larger weight room and address other disparities between its men's and women's tournaments.","nprID":979596524,"nprURL":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.npr.org\u002F2021\u002F03\u002F20\u002F979596524\u002Funder-fire-the-ncaa-apologizes-and-unveils-new-weight-room-for-womens-tournament","dateline":"","superTitleURL":"","postType":"","isBreaking":false,"isDeveloping":false,"relatedLinksLabel":"Related:","broadcastType":null,"broadcastDate":"","broadcastTime":"","itunesEpType":"","itunesEpNum":"","itunesTitle":"","itunesSummary":"","itunesExplicit":false,"volume":3,"disqus":null,"googlePick":false,"suppressAudio":false,"amp":false,"updateDate":"2021-03-21 Edition Sunday","images":[{"id":"977817747","title":"Fatima Roshanian, a journalist, scaled back her movements after she found her name on three different lists circulating on Afghan social media, claiming to be of people the Taliban want to kill.","caption":"Fatima Roshanian, a journalist, scaled back her movements after she found her name on three different lists circulating on Afghan social media, claiming to be of people the Taliban want to kill. (Kiana Hayeri for NPR)","credit":"Kiana Hayeri for NPR","url":"https:\u002F\u002Fmedia.npr.org\u002Fassets\u002Fimg\u002F2021\u002F03\u002F16\u002Fhayeri_npr_nimrokh_0131_slide-bc49322099e237ef560b12d614bf7e8d1165c786.jpg","sizes":{"thumb":{"width":0,"height":0,"file":"https:\u002F\u002Fmedia.npr.org\u002Fassets\u002Fimg\u002F2021\u002F03\u002F16\u002Fhayeri_npr_nimrokh_0131_slide-bc49322099e237ef560b12d614bf7e8d1165c786.jpg?s=12","type":"thumb"},"medium":{"width":0,"height":0,"file":"https:\u002F\u002Fmedia.npr.org\u002Fassets\u002Fimg\u002F2021\u002F03\u002F16\u002Fhayeri_npr_nimrokh_0131_slide-bc49322099e237ef560b12d614bf7e8d1165c786.jpg?s=4","type":"medium"},"large":{"width":0,"height":0,"file":"https:\u002F\u002Fmedia.npr.org\u002Fassets\u002Fimg\u002F2021\u002F03\u002F16\u002Fhayeri_npr_nimrokh_0131_slide-bc49322099e237ef560b12d614bf7e8d1165c786.jpg?s=6","type":"large"},"full":{"width":0,"height":0,"file":"https:\u002F\u002Fmedia.npr.org\u002Fassets\u002Fimg\u002F2021\u002F03\u002F16\u002Fhayeri_npr_nimrokh_0131_slide-bc49322099e237ef560b12d614bf7e8d1165c786.jpg","type":"full"},"square":{"width":0,"height":0,"file":"https:\u002F\u002Fmedia.npr.org\u002Fassets\u002Fimg\u002F2021\u002F03\u002F16\u002Fhayeri_npr_nimrokh_0131_sq-13b75ce8dbf90f9dfb330e22216cd7aabc97a637.jpg","type":"square"}}}],"content":["KABUL, Afghanistan — It's not the risk of contracting COVID-19 that keeps journalist Fatima Roshanian home. It's the murders.","Roshanian scaled back her movements after she found her name on three different lists circulating on Afghan social media, claiming to be of people the Taliban want to kill. On one list, she's number 11.","\"They are after people who are well-known, who are against the values of this society, who speak out,\" she says.","It's not the first time Roshanian has been threatened. She's offended plenty of conservatives in her life in her job as the editor of an Afghan feminist magazine, \u003Cem\u003ENimrokh\u003C\u002Fem\u003E. It covers topics like sex, virginity, periods, marital affairs — all shocking by Afghan standards. But this time, she says, she's taking the threats more seriously, because \"you see journalists and other people are being killed everyday, everywhere, on the streets, in their homes, in the bazaars.\"","\u003Cfigure class=\"article-fig size-large\"\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"size-large article-image\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fmedia.npr.org\u002Fassets\u002Fimg\u002F2021\u002F03\u002F16\u002Fhayeri_npr_nimrokh_003_slide-b02d991eff49baa200bd09434a3459a4cf594ac0.jpg?s=6\"\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"article-fig-caption article-fig-caption--pull\"\u003ERoshanian works with Allahdad Dadgar, a freelance graphic designer, to wrap their special issue for International Women's day at the \u003Cem\u003ENimrokh \u003C\u002Fem\u003Eoffice, which is a two bedroom apartment above a supermarket in Kabul. (Kiana Hayeri for NPR)\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E","Over the past six months, shadowy assassins have murdered influential and prominent Afghans, including journalists, human rights activists, judicial workers, doctors and clerics. The killings began escalating last September, when peace talks began between the Afghan government and the Taliban.","It should have been a time marked by hope. Instead, the United Nations said in a February report that more than \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Funama.unmissions.org\u002Fsites\u002Fdefault\u002Ffiles\u002Fafghanistan_protection_of_civilians_report_2020_revs3.pdf\"\u003E700 people\u003C\u002Fa\u003E had been murdered in targeted killings in 2020. More than 540 were wounded. The U.N. noted it was a 45% increase in the number of civilian casualties compared to 2019. So far this year, more than 60 people have been the victims of targeted killings, according to an NPR tally of incidents reported by \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftwitter.com\u002Frivmonitoring\"\u003Ean Afghan violence monitoring site\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.","\"It has been unprecedented,\" says Shaharzad Akbar, the chairperson of the Afghanistan Independent Human Rights Commission. She says she's never seen anything like the scope of these assassinations, \"in terms of how many people have been killed, in a short time period and how it hasn't stopped.\"","The killed include \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fgandhara.rferl.org\u002Fa\u002Fkabul-university-professor-enikass-journalists-afghanistan\u002F31130856.html\"\u003EFaiz Mohammad Fayez,\u003C\u002Fa\u003E a \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fserateshgh.com\u002Finternational\u002Fassassination-of-90-religious-scholars-in-past-year-in-afghanistan\u002F\"\u003Ereligious scholar\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and university professor, gunned down earlier this month as he walked to a mosque for morning prayers. They include the surgeon \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.khaama.com\u002Fhospital-surgeon-murdered-by-unknown-gunmen-22332221\u002F\"\u003EDr. Khalil-ur-Rahman Narmgo\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, who was \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftolonews.com\u002Findex.php\u002Fafghanistan-170240\"\u003Egunned down\u003C\u002Fa\u003E in February.","They include prosecutor \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.khaama.com\u002Fnds-kills-key-intelligence-daesh-official-in-nangarhar-4645333\u002F\"\u003EMirwais Samadi\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fpajhwok.com\u002F2021\u002F03\u002F08\u002Fmaidan-wardak-prosecutor-gunned-down-in-kabul\u002F\"\u003Eshot dead by gunmen\u003C\u002Fa\u003E while \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2021\u002F03\u002F04\u002Fworld\u002Fasia\u002Fafghan-casualty-report-march-2021.html\"\u003Eon his way to work\u003C\u002Fa\u003E; and television presenter \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.bbc.com\u002Fnews\u002Fworld-asia-55256427\"\u003EMalala Maiwand\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, killed alongside her driver in December. \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.reuters.com\u002Farticle\u002Fafghanistan-attack-media-int-idUSKCN2AW2GE\"\u003EThree other women \u003C\u002Fa\u003Efrom the same station where Maiwand worked were shot dead in March.","In response, one Afghan media rights group has flung up shelters for threatened journalists. \"They don't have any safe place, so they come here,\" says \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftwitter.com\u002FFaiziWahida\"\u003EWahida Faizi\u003C\u002Fa\u003E of the \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftwitter.com\u002Fajsc_afg\"\u003EAfghan Journalists Safety Committee\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. Faizi says the group is also distributing bullet-proof vests and helping some of those threatened leave the country.","\u003Cfigure class=\"article-fig size-large\"\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"size-large article-image\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fmedia.npr.org\u002Fassets\u002Fimg\u002F2021\u002F03\u002F16\u002Fhayeri_npr_nimrokh_009_vert-acf6f78b5d22bdf366b93dc49b471bf1cd3ac54d.jpg?s=6\"\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"article-fig-caption article-fig-caption--pull\"\u003ERoshanian has been threatened before, but this time, she says she's taking the threats more seriously. \"You see journalists and other people are being killed everyday, everywhere, on the streets, in their homes, in the bazaars.\" (Kiana Hayeri for NPR)\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E","\u003Cstrong\u003EIdentifying the killers \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E","It's not clear who is behind the carnage. ISIS has claimed responsibility for the murders of five women: Maiwand, her three colleagues and a doctor.","The U.S. and other Western nations blame the Taliban. \"The Taliban bears responsibility for the majority of this targeted violence,\" noted a January statement from the \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Faf.usembassy.gov\u002Fstatement-on-continuation-of-assassinations-kidnappings-and-destruction-of-vital-infrastructure\u002F\"\u003EU.S. embassy in Kabul\u003C\u002Fa\u003E signed by the European Union, NATO's senior civilian representative in Afghanistan and the diplomatic missions for 12 Western countries.","Many Afghans agree, like one feminist who requested anonymity because she recently received a death threat over Facebook. She believes it's because she helped women flee their violent husbands.","In an interview with NPR, she said it's no coincidence that the killings stepped up after Afghan peace talks began.","\"The Taliban are demonstrating their power,\" she says, a way for them to flex their muscle in negotiations, while also silencing those who might disagree with them and their hard-line methods. \"They are targeting journalists and civil society — people who can raise their voice. People who can tell the international community what is happening. They want to shut them up.\"","The Taliban deny responsibility. \"This is a false propaganda of the enemy,\" said a spokesman, who uses the name Zabihullah Mujahid. He blamed Afghan government intelligence officials for the murders.","Roshanian thinks it's more complicated. She believes the death lists being shared on social media are actually worked up by locals: conservatives, Taliban sympathizers, people with grudges.","She thinks they're \u003Cem\u003Edoxing\u003C\u002Fem\u003E for the Taliban — revealing the identities of people online in order to entice militants to harm them. \"These lists tell the Taliban: these are the people who are making trouble, who are putting new thoughts in women's heads. They identify us so the Taliban can kill us.\"","\u003Cfigure class=\"article-fig size-large\"\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"size-large article-image\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fmedia.npr.org\u002Fassets\u002Fimg\u002F2021\u002F03\u002F16\u002Fhayeri_npr_nimrokh_016_slide-63d3235259414a5da5bb561a7ef2c11ca6055b3b.jpg?s=6\"\u003E\u003Cfigcaption class=\"article-fig-caption article-fig-caption--pull\"\u003ERoshanian, who runs the women's magazine, thinks it's more complicated. She believes the death lists being shared on social media are actually worked up by locals: conservatives, Taliban sympathisers, people with grudges. (Kiana Hayeri for NPR)\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E","Some caution other hands may be at work.","One cleric, Ustadh Abdul Salaam Abed, who survived a bomb blast that struck his vehicle, believes Afghan intelligence officials are also targeting people.","\"Intelligence has a direct hand,\" he says. \"There are people in the system who are scared of the nation's voices, scared of the coming peace,\" he says. He punctuated his conversation with nervous giggles, saying he could hear beeps on the line that he believed were a result of his phone being bugged.","Officials for the Afghan government declined to comment for this story.","\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amnesty.org\u002Fen\u002Fdocuments\u002Fasa11\u002F3845\u002F2021\u002Fen\u002F\"\u003EAmnesty International recently criticized the government\u003C\u002Fa\u003E for not moving on the creation of a body that would protect human rights defenders. Other diplomats have said that while the government is investigating these murders, they have done little to communicate with victims' families or the media on the steps they are taking to address the violence.","\u003Cstrong\u003EA mission to intimidate \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E","Akbar, from the human rights commission, says even if the killers are unknown, the intention is clear. \"It's a deliberate attempt to kill people or scare them away from the country,\" she says. \"Unfortunately, it has worked.\"","The killings are already impacting female reporters in particular. Faizi's organization \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftwitter.com\u002Fajsc_afg\u002Fstatus\u002F1368834674450178052\u002Fphoto\u002F1\"\u003Erecently published a report\u003C\u002Fa\u003E noting that more than 300 women — one-fifth of all who work in Afghan media — have quit their jobs as a result of the killings, and because of insecurities surrounding COVID-19.","They include a young reporter who requested anonymity because out of concern attention would trigger a death threat. She fought her family to become a reporter — a profession they said was not honorable for a woman. She found a job, but then the murders began. Fearing for her life, she quit. \"Now the world feels dark,\" she tells NPR. \"I am always thinking: what if this is permanent? What if I never work again?\"","There's been other secondary victims of these killings, too. Karima Rahimyar, a school teacher and girls education activist, received threats over Facebook. She, defiantly, continues to work. But she pulled her own daughters out of university — until the danger passes, or until they can flee. \"I'm scared for my daughters,\" she says.","Roshanian, the feminist magazine editor, now works from home, but her friends urge her to flee. \"They all tell me, 'Fatima, the things you are doing right now for this country is useless. It won't impact anyone.'\" She responds: \"If you are thinking like this, and I start thinking like you – what will be left here?\"","\u003Cem\u003EHadid reported from Islamabad; Ghani from Kabul.\u003C\u002Fem\u003E  ","\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.npr.org\u002F2021\u002F03\u002F21\u002F977797909\u002Famid-a-wave-of-targeted-killings-in-afghanistan-shes-no-11-on-a-murder-list\" Mass. Map And Case Count: Breaking Down Coronavirus Here In Charts","subhead":null,"publishDate":"2020-03-09 17:03:38","updatedDate":"2021-03-20 17:39:25","relativeURL":"\u002Fcommonhealth\u002F2020\u002F03\u002F09\u002Fcoronavirus-cases-massachusetts-map","apiURL":"http:\u002F\u002Fapi.wbur.org\u002Fstories?date=2020-03-09&slug=coronavirus-cases-massachusetts-map&sources=commonhealth","externalURL":"","shortLink":"https:\u002F\u002Fwbur.fm\u002F2VZpemY","miniExcerpt":"","excerpt":"Take a closer look at trends in the state with these interactive maps and charts.","bylines":[{"name":"Roberto Scalese","nameLastFirst":"Scalese, Roberto","slug":"roberto-scalese","wordpressID":498619,"content":["Roberto Scalese is a digital producer and editor."],"apiURL":"http:\u002F\u002Fapi.wbur.org\u002Fpeople\u002Froberto-scalese","relativeURL":"\u002Finside\u002Fstaff\u002Froberto-scalese","organization":"wbur","embedMeta":null,"shortBio":"Roberto Scalese is a digital producer and editor. ","twitter":"@BertoScalese","facebook":null,"title":"Digital Producer","type":"newsroom","channels":["news"],"photo":"https:\u002F\u002Fd279m997dpfwgl.cloudfront.net\u002Fwp\u002F2016\u002F06\u002FScalese_Roberto-2019-1k-2-600x600.jpg","website":null,"email":"rscalese@bu.edu"},{"name":"Ally Jarmanning","nameLastFirst":"Jarmanning, Ally","slug":"ally-manning","wordpressID":107659,"content":["Ally is a senior reporter focused on criminal justice and police accountability.  She champions data and public records in the WBUR newsroom, reporting her own stories and working with fellow reporters on projects and daily news. She started at WBUR writing for \u003Cem\u003EMorning Edition\u003C\u002Fem\u003E and later worked for the digital team, deepening her work in \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wbur.org\u002Fcommonhealth\u002F2020\u002F03\u002F09\u002Fcoronavirus-cases-massachusetts-map\"\u003Edata-based journalism\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and audience engagement. Before jumping into radio, she reported for \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.dispatch.com\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003Enewspapers\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.boston.com\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"\u003Ewebsites\u003C\u002Fa\u003E in Massachusetts and Ohio.","A South Shore native, she graduated from Boston University with a degree in journalism."],"apiURL":"http:\u002F\u002Fapi.wbur.org\u002Fpeople\u002Fally-manning","relativeURL":"\u002Finside\u002Fstaff\u002Fally-manning","organization":"wbur","embedMeta":null,"shortBio":"Ally is a senior reporter focused on criminal justice and police accountability.","twitter":"@allyjarmanning","facebook":null,"title":"Senior Reporter","type":"newsroom","channels":["news"],"photo":"https:\u002F\u002Fd279m997dpfwgl.cloudfront.net\u002Fwp\u002F2016\u002F12\u002Fallison-manning.jpg","website":null,"email":"allyjar@bu.edu"}],"nprID":null,"nprTranscriptID":null,"nprURL":null,"dateline":"","superTitle":"Coronavirus Coverage","superTitleURL":"\u002Fcoronavirus","content":["\u003Ch2\u003EThe Latest Numbers\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E","\u003Cspan data-breakout=\"true\" data-index=\"1\" data-type=\"flourish\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","The above numbers include the cases and deaths \u003Cem\u003Econfirmed\u003C\u002Fem\u003E each day by the Department of Public Health (DPH). But because of a lag in reporting, a case could have been \u003Cem\u003Ediagnosed\u003C\u002Fem\u003E or a person may have died earlier. To get a more accurate picture of the day-by-day change, scroll down to the interactive charts below.","Each day, the state releases a dashboard of its data tracking cases and deaths by age, race, sex and geography. You can look at the complete data \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.mass.gov\u002Finfo-details\u002Fcovid-19-response-reporting\"\u003Ein the state's daily report\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.","____","\u003Ch2\u003EVaccinations\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E","\u003Cspan data-breakout=\"true\" data-index=\"2\" data-type=\"flourish\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","\u003Cspan data-breakout=\"true\" data-index=\"3\" data-type=\"flourish\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","You can also find these charts \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wbur.org\u002Fcommonhealth\u002F2020\u002F12\u002F23\u002Fmassachusetts-vaccine-delivery-phases-safety-faq\"\u003Ehere\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, where you'll also find context on the state's vaccine distribution plans and execution.","____","\u003Ch2\u003EYour Community\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E","The below map reflects state health officials' risk determination for each community in Massachusetts. Municipalities with the highest rates of infection are marked in red and considered \"high risk,\" followed by yellow and green. Communities in grey have the fewest cases and lowest rates of transmission. More information about the risk levels \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wbur.org\u002Fcommonhealth\u002F2020\u002F04\u002F16\u002Fcoronavirus-cases-by-city-and-town-in-massachusetts\"\u003Eis here\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.","\u003Cspan data-breakout=\"true\" data-index=\"4\" data-type=\"flourish\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","The state updates data on deaths and cases by city and town once a week, on Thursdays. Click on the interactive above to see the latest case count in your community.","For more granular information about your community, plus the latest information about ongoing coronavirus clusters in the state, \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wbur.org\u002Fcommonhealth\u002F2020\u002F04\u002F16\u002Fcoronavirus-cases-by-city-and-town-in-massachusetts\"\u003Eclick here\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.","____","\u003Ch2\u003ETracking New Confirmed Cases And Deaths\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E","Each of the graphs below track the number of new cases or deaths by the day diagnosed. It often takes a few days for hospitals, labs and other facilities to report the data.","You may note that the charts show a sharp drop-off for the last few days. Keep in mind that may not mean an actual decrease in the numbers, but a delay in the state's reporting.","\u003Cspan data-breakout=\"true\" data-index=\"5\" data-type=\"flourish\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","\u003Cspan data-breakout=\"true\" data-index=\"6\" data-type=\"flourish\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","____","\u003Ch2\u003ETracking The State's Positive Test Rate\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E","The graph below shows how many tests taken by residents have come back positive — that's the state's positive test rate.","The orange line shows that rate excluding results from colleges and universities, where students and staff are tested multiple times a week. Because of that, the same person can contribute multiple negative tests and inadvertently skew the positive rate downward. In providing the second, higher rate by removing higher ed results, the state data offers a cleaner picture of the actual positive rate in Massachusetts.","\u003Cspan data-breakout=\"true\" data-index=\"7\" data-type=\"flourish\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","____","\u003Ch2\u003ELong-Term Care Facility Cases And Deaths\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E","Cases inside of the state's long-term care facilities are of particular concern because the coronavirus has been especially dangerous for older people and people with existing health conditions. Deaths in these facilities account for almost two-thirds of the lives lost to COVID-19 during the pandemic. The case data provided by the state combined resident and staff cases, and does not include assisted-living facilities.","\u003Cspan data-breakout=\"true\" data-index=\"8\" data-type=\"flourish\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","____","\u003Ch2\u003ECoronavirus In The Hospital\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E","A key metric in combating the pandemic has been hospitalization: We want to make sure that any wave of infections does not exceed our ability to treat people with the most serious cases. The following charts reflect the current capacity at the state's hospitals.","\u003Cspan data-breakout=\"true\" data-index=\"9\" data-type=\"flourish\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","\u003Cspan data-breakout=\"true\" data-index=\"10\" data-type=\"flourish\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","\u003Cspan data-breakout=\"true\" data-index=\"11\" data-type=\"flourish\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","____","\u003Ch2\u003EThe Pandemic To Date In Massachusetts\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E","\u003Cspan data-index=\"12\" data-type=\"flourish\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","____","\u003Ca id=\"nl-form-coronavirus\" href=\"#signup\"\u003ESign up\u003C\u002Fa\u003E","\u003Cspan data-index=\"13\" data-type=\"iframe\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E"],"enhanced":false,"seriesMeta":null,"iframeHero":null,"postType":"post","isBreaking":false,"isDeveloping":false,"relatedLinks":[{"id":194057,"url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wbur.org\u002Fcommonhealth\u002F2020\u002F04\u002F16\u002Fcoronavirus-cases-by-city-and-town-in-massachusetts","prefix":"Chart:","title":"Town-By-Town Data","index":1},{"id":196603,"url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wbur.org\u002Ftag\u002Fcoronavirus-vaccines","prefix":"Latest:","title":"Mass. data-breakout=\"true\" data-index=\"6\" data-type=\"flourish\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E"},"embed-7":{"id":7,"parentID":558290,"type":"flourish","attributes":{"id":"4297866","breakout":"true"},"body":"","placeholder":"\u003Cspan data-breakout=\"true\" data-index=\"7\" data-type=\"flourish\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E"},"embed-8":{"id":8,"parentID":558290,"type":"flourish","attributes":{"id":"4298355","breakout":"true"},"body":"","placeholder":"\u003Cspan data-breakout=\"true\" data-index=\"8\" data-type=\"flourish\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E"},"embed-9":{"id":9,"parentID":558290,"type":"flourish","attributes":{"id":"4393992","breakout":"true"},"body":"","placeholder":"\u003Cspan data-breakout=\"true\" data-index=\"9\" data-type=\"flourish\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E"},"embed-10":{"id":10,"parentID":558290,"type":"flourish","attributes":{"id":"4299602","breakout":"true"},"body":"","placeholder":"\u003Cspan data-breakout=\"true\" data-index=\"10\" data-type=\"flourish\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E"},"embed-11":{"id":11,"parentID":558290,"type":"flourish","attributes":{"id":"4299685","breakout":"true"},"body":"","placeholder":"\u003Cspan data-breakout=\"true\" data-index=\"11\"
