data-type=\"flourish\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E"},"embed-13":{"id":13,"parentID":558290,"type":"iframe","attributes":{"src":"https:\u002F\u002Fdev.wbur.org\u002Fsuperplayer\u002F?source=coronavirusbriefly","pym":"true","align":"none"},"body":"","placeholder":"\u003Cspan data-index=\"13\" data-type=\"iframe\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E"}},"images":[{"id":2885,"url":"https:\u002F\u002Fd279m997dpfwgl.cloudfront.net\u002Fconfig\u002F2021\u002F03\u002F10\u002FScreen%20Shot%202021-03-10%20at%207.49.18%20AM.png","title":"","caption":"","credit":"","nprID":null,"index":1,"isOverride":true,"filename":"Screen Shot 2021-03-10 at 7.49.18 AM.png"}],"index":1,"editorCreated":true,"displayAsPullquote":false,"isAd":false,"videos":[]}]},{"id":12660,"component_id":6,"created_at":"2020-12-10 13:23:46","updated_at":"2021-03-21 16:00:03","channel":"wbur","title":"Vaccine Coverage","url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wbur.org\u002Ftag\u002Fcoronavirus-vaccines","linkTitle":"","contentLimit":4,"index":4,"endsWith":"","allowDupes":false,"icons":false,"locked":false,"display":[],"query":{},"meta":{},"dateDisplay":"publish","adType":"billboard","cards":[],"component":{"id":6,"created_at":"2016-06-08 04:58:08","updated_at":"2016-06-08 04:58:08","minimumItems":4,"maximumItems":4,"itemMultiplier":null,"isContentTarget":true,"title":"Features","type":"stories","supportsAd":true,"supportsRelLinks":false,"supportsSectionBar":true,"requiresImage":false,"fullContent":false},"contentItems":[{"guid":"25874211-2be3-421b-8787-07eef308c981","id":668488,"channel":"CommonHealth","fullChannel":null,"channelType":"section","program":null,"channelURL":"\u002Fcommonhealth","wordpressSlug":"it-feels-like-a-gut-punch-some-mass-residents-are-left-hunting-for-second-covid-vaccine-doses","wordpressID":668488,"source":"commonhealth","headline":"'It Feels Like A Gut Punch': Some Mass. Residents Are Left Hunting For Second COVID Vaccine Doses","subhead":null,"publishDate":"2021-03-18 06:00:45","updatedDate":"2021-03-18 16:26:46","relativeURL":"\u002Fcommonhealth\u002F2021\u002F03\u002F18\u002Fit-feels-like-a-gut-punch-some-mass-residents-are-left-hunting-for-second-covid-vaccine-doses","apiURL":"http:\u002F\u002Fapi.wbur.org\u002Fstories?date=2021-03-18&slug=it-feels-like-a-gut-punch-some-mass-residents-are-left-hunting-for-second-covid-vaccine-doses&sources=commonhealth","externalURL":"","shortLink":"https:\u002F\u002Fwbur.fm\u002F30U1gKV","miniExcerpt":"","excerpt":"As Massachusetts moves to allow more residents to get coronavirus vaccines, there's stiff competition for a limited number of appointments. And some people seeking second doses may be getting left behind.","bylines":[{"name":"Angus Chen","nameLastFirst":"Chen, Angus","slug":"angus-chen","wordpressID":496276,"content":["Angus Chen is a reporter for WBUR's CommonHealth."],"apiURL":"http:\u002F\u002Fapi.wbur.org\u002Fpeople\u002Fangus-chen","relativeURL":"\u002Finside\u002Fstaff\u002Fangus-chen","organization":"wbur","embedMeta":null,"shortBio":"Angus Chen is a reporter for WBUR's CommonHealth.","twitter":"angRchen","facebook":null,"title":"Reporter, CommonHealth","type":"newsroom","channels":["commonhealth"],"photo":"https:\u002F\u002Fd279m997dpfwgl.cloudfront.net\u002Fwp\u002F2019\u002F07\u002F20190814_angus-chen-sq-600x600.jpg","website":null,"email":"cangus@bu.edu"}],"nprID":null,"nprTranscriptID":null,"nprURL":null,"dateline":"","superTitle":"Coronavirus Coverage","superTitleURL":"\u002Fcoronavirus","content":["\u003Cem\u003ETraducido en español por \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Felplaneta.com\u002Fnews\u002F2021\u002Fmar\u002F19\u002Fconseguir-la-segunda-dosis-se-convierte-en-desafio-para-algunos-residentes-de-ma\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003EEl Planeta Media\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fem\u003E","Stephanie McPherson can’t find coronavirus vaccine appointments for some of her staff members who need them anywhere. She’s the administrator at the Alliance Health at Rosewood nursing home in Peabody, where most employees were able to get fully vaccinated thanks to CVS and the state Department of Public Health, which set up vaccine clinics at the home on three separate occasions.","But, she says, some of her employees only made it to the third and final clinic.","“We had a few who decided at the very end that 'yes, I definitely want this vaccine.' Two were actually sick with COVID during the first two clinics, so they had to wait until the third,” McPherson says.","She promised that she’d be able to get them second doses, even though no more clinics were coming to the nursing home. The staff at DPH told her that anyone who got their first dose should be able to find a second appointment at a mass vaccination site, community clinic or pharmacy.","\u003C!--more--\u003E","“You should be able to get an appointment, super easy. I’ll help you with it,” she relayed to her staff.","But the process has\u003Cdel\u003E\u003C\u002Fdel\u003E been anything but easy. In the weeks since those final employees were vaccinated, McPherson’s been scouring the web to find her staff second doses. Every time she looks, \u003Cdel\u003E\u003C\u002Fdel\u003Ethe appointments are all taken. That makes her feel like the state's vaccine rollout left them behind, and now there are too many eligible people and too few vaccines.","\u003Cspan data-index=\"1\" data-type=\"caption\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","“I can’t find them an appointment, and they can’t find an appointment. It feels like a gut punch to me that I can’t deliver for my staff,” McPherson says. “It just didn’t feel like we were done with health care [workers] yet, and all of a sudden it moved to other groups. Which was wonderful but, at the same time, there’s not enough allocated doses for all those people. It’s incredibly frustrating.”","That problem might get worse in the coming weeks. The state announced Wednesday that vaccine eligibility will open for \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wbur.org\u002Fcommonhealth\u002F2021\u002F03\u002F17\u002Fbaker-massachusetts-full-vaccine-timeline-rollout\"\u003Emore people\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, starting with residents age 60 and older, and some types of workers, on March 22.","It's unclear exactly how many Massachusetts residents are currently hunting for second doses, but McPherson’s staff aren’t the only ones stuck in this vaccine limbo. The customer help line at CIC Health has received dozens of calls from people who didn’t schedule a second appointment right after they got their first shot at a CIC Health-run mass vaccination center, a \u003Cdel\u003E\u003C\u002Fdel\u003Ecompany spokesperson told WBUR.","Guests who are vaccinated at CIC Health-run sites are supposed to receive a QR code, a type of bar code readable by a smartphone or computer, that allows them to book their second shot. But in some cases, people didn’t receive that QR code, or they simply forgot to book an appointment using the code, which expires after a couple of days.","At that point, the patients face a dilemma. The state's vaccine web portal doesn't allow them to sign up for just a second dose. All they can do is call the state’s 2-1-1 line or CIC Health, but often there are simply no appointments available.","\u003Cspan data-index=\"2\" data-type=\"caption\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","CIC Health says the state has added a new system at mass vaccination centers that will send a special link via text or email after people receive their first dose. That link can be used to sign up for a second appointment.","At CIC Health's sites, staff members also check in with guests before they leave to make sure they get a second appointment and help them through the sign up process if they need it. Most people don’t leave without getting that second spot. But for those who do find themselves hunting for a second appointment, frustration abounds.","Part of the problem is that members of high priority groups like health care workers and people 75 and older now have to compete with a growing list of people, including educators, those with two or more health conditions that put them at a higher risk from COVID, and others, all for the same limited number of doses. At the moment, there just aren’t enough for everyone who is eligible and wants to be vaccinated, says Dr. Paul Biddinger, chief of emergency preparedness at Massachusetts General Hospital.","“It’s a challenge we have to address and one that will be made easier to deal with when we have more supply,” Biddinger says. “Hospitals, clinics and other vaccinators are being asked to basically use 100% of supply within 10 days, so you don’t have extra on shelves. It makes it extra hard to give an additional second dose when it’s not anticipated.”","A Department of Public Health spokesperson said the state will ensure that everyone who received a first dose will also get a second dose, although the DPH doesn't have information on how many people are in-between shots. The state also provides some \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.mass.gov\u002Finfo-details\u002Fcovid-19-vaccination-locations#scheduling-a-second-dose-appointment-\"\u003Eguidance\u003C\u002Fa\u003E on its website for people seeking second dose appointments.","The schedule for receiving a second dose does have some wiggle room, Biddinger adds. Guidance from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says there’s no harm in getting it a couple of weeks late.","“We reassure people that the CDC has said very clearly you have up to six weeks [to get the next shot] without any concern,” he says.","The CDC guidance also says it’s better to delay a second dose up to 6 weeks from the first injection than to \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.cdc.gov\u002Fvaccines\u002Fcovid-19\u002Finfo-by-product\u002Fclinical-considerations.html\"\u003Emix shots of the Johnson &amp; Johnson, Moderna and Pfizer vaccines\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. However, in cases where someone cannot receive the same vaccine they did for the first shot, federal guidance says one of the other coronavirus vaccines can be used to complete the vaccination process.","That’s not particularly reassuring to McPherson, though. State guidance says you must get the same type of vaccine for both doses. And she says she might feel nervous mixing and matching vaccines, and she doesn’t want that for her co-workers either.","“Then they’d have to be the ones who are going to have to feel like the guinea pigs when they mix doses from two different vaccines,” she says.","McPherson says her employees &mdash; and health care workers on the front lines in general &mdash; should get the best protection that science and society have to offer. After all, she says, every day they've gone to work in the last year, they've taken risks.","“They showed up to work every day in the height of the pandemic. Not only showing up, but basically not leaving because they knew we needed help,” she says. “They deserve to be able to have that sense of security at work.”","\u003Chr \u002F\u003E","\u003Cem\u003EEditor's note: This story has been updated to reflect a new system put in place to help people sign up for second doses.\u003C\u002Fem\u003E"],"enhanced":false,"seriesMeta":null,"iframeHero":null,"postType":"post","isBreaking":false,"isDeveloping":false,"relatedLinks":[],"relatedLinksLabel":"Related:","broadcastType":"segment","broadcastDate":"2021-03-18 06:45:00","broadcastTime":"06:45:00","itunesEpType":"","itunesEpNum":0,"itunesTitle":"","itunesSummary":"","itunesExplicit":false,"volume":3,"disqus":null,"enableComments":false,"googlePick":false,"suppressAudio":false,"amp":true,"audioDatetime":"1616071726","pullquotes":[],"taxonomy":[{"id":61,"type":"category","name":"Boston","description":"","slug":"boston","series":false,"count":49655},{"id":69,"type":"category","name":"Health","description":"","slug":"health","series":false,"count":16510},{"id":200,"type":"tag","name":"WBUR's Morning Edition","description":"Local content from WBUR's Morning Edition broadcasts","slug":"morning-edition","series":false,"count":5085},{"id":5222,"type":"tag","name":"Novel Coronavirus","description":"WBUR's ongoing coverage of the new coronavirus.","slug":"novel-coronavirus","series":false,"count":2997},{"id":5244,"type":"tag","name":"Coronavirus Liveblog","description":"WBUR news stories that appear in our continually updated liveblog on the coronavirus outbreak in Massachusetts.","slug":"coronavirus-liveblog","series":false,"count":982},{"id":5286,"type":"tag","name":"Spanish Translations","description":"WBUR has a partnership with El Planeta to translate certain stories into Spanish. Charlie Baker tweeted\u003C\u002Fa\u003E that one million people have received either two doses of an mRNA vaccine (made by both Moderna and Pfizer), or a single dose of Johnson &amp; Johnson's DNA-based vaccine.","The state began administering vaccinations in mid-December, starting with COVID-facing health care workers. Over time, the vaccination program grew and now includes educators in K-12 schools, people ages 65 and above and people who have two medical conditions known to exacerbate COVID-19 symptoms.","On Wednesday, Baker rolled out an \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wbur.org\u002Fcommonhealth\u002F2021\u002F03\u002F17\u002Fbaker-massachusetts-full-vaccine-timeline-rollout\"\u003Eeligibility timetable\u003C\u002Fa\u003E for all other residents in the state. Under the new schedule, all Massachusetts residents ages 16 and older will be eligible for vaccination by Patriots' Day, April 19.","Overall, 14.47% of Bay Staters have been fully vaccinated, ranking 12th among the states in that category, according to data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.","Baker has been criticized for the slow start to the state's vaccination rollout, and for the technical snafus with the state's vaccination website, which initially could not handle the crush of users vying for precious few vaccination appointments. And local health officials have decried the state's continually shifting plan of attack, particularly the decision to abandon a long-held plan to vaccinate through local clinics run by public boards of health in favor of mass vaccination sites operated by private firms."],"enhanced":false,"seriesMeta":null,"iframeHero":null,"postType":"post","isBreaking":false,"isDeveloping":false,"relatedLinks":[],"relatedLinksLabel":"Related:","broadcastType":"","broadcastDate":"","broadcastTime":"","itunesEpType":"","itunesEpNum":0,"itunesTitle":"","itunesSummary":"","itunesExplicit":false,"volume":3,"disqus":null,"enableComments":false,"googlePick":false,"suppressAudio":false,"amp":true,"audioDatetime":null,"pullquotes":[],"taxonomy":[{"id":61,"type":"category","name":"Boston","description":"","slug":"boston","series":false,"count":49655},{"id":69,"type":"category","name":"Health","description":"","slug":"health","series":false,"count":16510},{"id":73,"type":"category","name":"News","description":"","slug":"news","series":false,"count":58847},{"id":5222,"type":"tag","name":"Novel Coronavirus","description":"WBUR's ongoing coverage of the new coronavirus.","slug":"novel-coronavirus","series":false,"count":2997},{"id":5244,"type":"tag","name":"Coronavirus Liveblog","description":"WBUR news stories that appear in our continually updated liveblog on the coronavirus outbreak in Massachusetts.","slug":"coronavirus-liveblog","series":false,"count":982},{"id":5465,"type":"tag","name":"Coronavirus Vaccine Coverage","description":"WBUR's ongoing coverage of the testing, approval processes, safety and distribution of vaccines to fight against the coronavirus pandemic.","slug":"coronavirus-vaccines","series":false,"count":284}],"audio":[],"embedMeta":null,"images":[{"type":"featured","url":"https:\u002F\u002Fd279m997dpfwgl.cloudfront.net\u002Fwp\u002F2021\u002F02\u002F0124_webstervacc-04.jpg","width":3000,"height":1741,"title":"COVID-19 vaccine vials. Baker Discusses His Plans To Further Reopen Massachusetts","subhead":null,"publishDate":"2021-03-19 08:40:55","updatedDate":"","relativeURL":"\u002Fnews\u002F2021\u002F03\u002F19\u002Fcharlie-baker-massachusetts-phase-four-vaccines","apiURL":"http:\u002F\u002Fapi.wbur.org\u002Fstories?date=2021-03-19&slug=charlie-baker-massachusetts-phase-four-vaccines&sources=news","externalURL":"","shortLink":"https:\u002F\u002Fwbur.fm\u002F3cTXWoW","miniExcerpt":"","excerpt":"Gov. Charlie Baker talked to Morning Edition's Bob Oakes Friday on the vaccination rollout and reopening the state.","bylines":[{"name":"Bob Oakes","nameLastFirst":"Oakes, Bob","slug":"bob-oakes","wordpressID":347,"content":["Bob Oakes has been WBUR's \u003Cem\u003EMorning Edition\u003C\u002Fem\u003E anchor since 1992. He is one of the most well-known and respected news people in New England, with a 20-year career in radio broadcasting, including 10 years with Boston's all-news commercial radio station WEEI and coverage of national issues for the CBS Radio Network."],"apiURL":"http:\u002F\u002Fapi.wbur.org\u002Fpeople\u002Fbob-oakes","relativeURL":"\u002Finside\u002Fstaff\u002Fbob-oakes","organization":"wbur","embedMeta":null,"shortBio":"Bob Oakes has been WBUR's Morning Edition anchor since 1992. ","twitter":"bob_oakes","facebook":null,"title":"Host, Morning Edition","type":"newsroom","channels":["cognoscenti","news"],"photo":"https:\u002F\u002Fd279m997dpfwgl.cloudfront.net\u002Fwp\u002F2016\u002F01\u002Fbob_oakes_square.jpg","website":null,"email":null},{"name":"Wilder Fleming","nameLastFirst":"Fleming, Wilder","slug":"wilder-fleming","wordpressID":475723,"content":["Wilder Fleming is a political producer at WBUR."],"apiURL":"http:\u002F\u002Fapi.wbur.org\u002Fpeople\u002Fwilder-fleming","relativeURL":"\u002Finside\u002Fstaff\u002Fwilder-fleming","organization":"wbur","embedMeta":null,"shortBio":"Wilder Fleming is a political producer at WBUR, focused on the path to November 2020.","twitter":"WilderFleming","facebook":null,"title":"Political Producer","type":"contributor","channels":["news"],"photo":"https:\u002F\u002Fd279m997dpfwgl.cloudfront.net\u002Fwp\u002F2019\u002F05\u002F0505_wilder-fleming-1k-600x600.jpg","website":null,"email":"wilderf@bu.edu"}],"nprID":null,"nprTranscriptID":null,"nprURL":null,"dateline":"","superTitle":"Coronavirus Coverage","superTitleURL":"\u002Fcoronavirus","content":["The Baker administration is downgrading the state's travel order to an advisory and moving forward to phase four &mdash; the final stage of the state's reopening plan.","Starting Monday, the state will allow venues including stadiums and arenas to reopen at reduced capacity. Indoor public gatherings will now be capped at 100. Earlier this week, the governor announced a timeline for \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wbur.org\u002Fcommonhealth\u002F2020\u002F12\u002F23\u002Fmassachusetts-vaccine-delivery-phases-safety-faq\"\u003Evaccinating all state residents\u003C\u002Fa\u003E over the age of 16.","To learn more, WBUR's \u003Cem\u003EMorning Edition \u003C\u002Fem\u003Ehost Bob Oakes spoke with Gov. Charlie Baker about these plans. Highlights from this interview have been lightly edited for clarity.","\u003Ch2\u003EInterview Highlights\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E","\u003Cstrong\u003EOn Baker's stated goal of achieving 70% vaccination in Mass. by the Fourth of July \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E","Well, the first thing I'd say is that we'll certainly have the capacity, you know, the people to deliver shots here in Massachusetts to make this happen. The big question mark &mdash; which has been the big question mark all along --  is how much supply will be available.","And  the good news there, which is why I'm optimistic about the timeline, is the Biden administration's task force told the governors earlier this week that they expect to not only up the shipments of Moderna and Pfizer, which I think as most people know is a two-dose vaccine, but to be able to dramatically scale the one-dose Johnson &amp; Johnson vaccine as well. And obviously the difference between one dose and being done, and two doses and being done, is pretty clear. And if they really do jack up the J&amp;J distribution in a big way, that will change the game not just for us in Massachusetts, but for everybody around the country.","\u003Cstrong\u003EOn worries over a potential fourth coronavirus wave expressed by public health officials like Anthony Fauci \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E","I think the vaccine process here is very much a race against time. I said that several weeks ago, which is why I was so frustrated about the message we were getting about supply. I do believe that we have the ability to dramatically speed up, double the number of shots we deliver every day in Massachusetts if the supply is there. And we pay a ton of attention to the data we get around positive test rates and around hospitalizations and deaths and ICU beds.","That stuff is critically important to us as we make decisions. And I would just say that some of the changes that we've made are, I would argue, consistent with the public health data. I mean, our hospitalization rate has dropped dramatically over the course of the past two months.","And our positive test rate, while it has leveled out, has leveled out at 2%, which is &mdash; below 2% -- which is significantly down. It was 8.5% in January. And I think in many ways, this whole thing has always been a balancing act. We constantly go back to the data that's available through the very large data collection infrastructure that we've built here in Massachusetts. And we constantly make adjustments based on that information.","But I do think the fact that we're vaccinating an extraordinary number of people, we're the number one state in the country on a per capita basis among all the large states, and we're putting all the vaccines we get from the feds into people's arms virtually immediately. So I feel that if their supply numbers pan out the way the administration has talked about it, we should have a heck of a lot more people vaccinated in a pretty short period of time.","\u003Cstrong\u003E On early criticism over the state's vaccination rollout and whether things could have been done differently \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E","Well, hindsight's a great thing, Bob, as we all know, but I think the biggest challenge that we and other states have faced is this whole issue around available supply and the actual order in which people are getting vaccinated in Massachusetts. We had a vaccine advisory committee that helped us develop the phased rollout. The phased rollout for the most part that we put out in December is pretty much the phased rollout we're on right now. We expected that sometime around Patriots Day we would be opening it up to everybody in Massachusetts and that we were going to start with some populations that were significantly important to both preserving life and protecting our health care system. And that's what we did.","The whole sort of essential worker community and teacher community &mdash; educator, community, child-care workers, teachers and K-12 staff &mdash; they're currently eligible and they were prioritized by us. That ... process, for the most part, has played out pretty much along the lines of the rollout plan that we announced back in December.","I do get the fact that everybody's anxious about this and people want to get vaccinated. That's why we have something like, oh boy, the last time I looked, I think we have 900,000-plus people signed up on our preregistration system, and we already have a million people who are fully vaccinated and 1.7 million who have had at least one shot.","That just speaks to how anxious people are to get their vaccine. And I get the fact that that anxiety plays a part in the way people feel about everything. And I'm completely sympathetic to that. And people who want to get vaccinated are going to get vaccinated. They are. It's just a question of how fast we can get this supply.","\u003Cstrong\u003EOn reopening Massachusetts schools amid concerns for public safety\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E","Well this has been an ongoing discussion for over a year. And I would say three things, Bob. The first is, the data from all over the globe &mdash; including here in Massachusetts &mdash; is overwhelmingly clear that schools with mitigation in place &mdash; and the mitigation for the most part is reasonably consistent from place to place to place &mdash; are safe places. And in Massachusetts, you have literally tens of thousands of public school kids and staff and teachers, private school kids and staff and teachers, and parochial school kids and staff and teachers, who've been in school, in-person five days a week since August. And they've done it safely and successfully.","But that's not just true here in Massachusetts. That's literally true all over the country and all over the world. And there have been numerous studies that have been done that say the same thing, which is that kids in school with the proper precautions in place is a safe place for kids and a safe place for grownups, and for adults. And I think the study that we did, which involved, you know, hundreds of thousands of staff and students around the three feet vs. six feet issue with regard to distance, was a pretty clear indicator that three feet works. And there's no difference between three feet and six feet and I'm glad that the CDC, based on the results of our study, is taking another look at this question.","And the final thing I would say, Bob: We're also the only state in the country that's made available to our school districts a weekly surveillance testing program for those that are interested in pursuing it, and we're paying for it. We have 177 school districts &mdash; that's half the districts in Massachusetts &mdash; that have signed up to participate in it. So I think we've got a lot of the protocols, tons of experiential data at this point, as well as some pretty solid surveillance tools that are available to schools. And, boy, the data coming from the pediatric community and from others in the sort of child welfare space about the impact of no in-person learning on kids is really disturbing.","\u003Cstrong\u003EOn rebuilding the travel and tourism economy \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E","There's probably no industry that's been hit harder than the one that relies on a business traveler or a tourist for their success. And that's part of the reason why we created one of the largest, if not the largest, sort of small-business support grant programs in the country.","But I think, what I guess I would say, Bob, is what that industry needs most of all is for countries to successfully implement a vaccine strategy and to get to the point where, you know, herd immunity, which you talked about at the beginning of this conversation, is basically in place &mdash; not just nationally here in the U.S., but globally.","The good news there is, as more and more vaccines become available, more and more people are getting vaccinated. But I think it's going to be ... a long ride on this one. And we'll do what we can with our resources and with federal resources to support the folks and the businesses in those industries as we work our way through this. But ... anybody who's been in Logan Airport any time in the past year knows how big a hit the global travel market has taken as a result of COVID.","\u003Cstrong\u003EOn the possibility of Baker running for a third term as governor\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E","So, Bob, I'm just curious to know if when you got to around the 15-year mark, anybody said to you, \"Gee, Bob, you've been doing this every single morning, five days a week, for 15 years. Do you really want to keep doing it?\" And I got a feeling your answer to that was, \"Yes.\" And as a result, we have been blessed to have you for way more than 15 years on our radio every morning, in our homes and in our cars.","I'm pulling your leg a little bit here, but I think the answer to the question is, both the lieutenant governor and I have been incredibly blessed to have the opportunity to do these jobs on behalf of the people of Massachusetts. I've lived here most of my life. I spent a big part of my career in state and local government. I really believe in the power and the importance of state and local government. And we have a ton of work to do even once we get past this pandemic to try to, you know, help people find a way back. We're doing a big report on the future of work, you know: What is work going to look like? Where are people going to work? Where are they going to live? How are they going to work, given everything that's changed as a result of the pandemic? There's plenty to do here."],"enhanced":false,"seriesMeta":null,"iframeHero":null,"postType":"post","isBreaking":false,"isDeveloping":false,"relatedLinks":[],"relatedLinksLabel":"Related:","broadcastType":"segment","broadcastDate":"2021-03-19 To Know About Coronavirus Vaccine Distribution In Mass.","subhead":null,"publishDate":"2020-12-23 15:59:38","updatedDate":"2021-03-19 12:17:17","relativeURL":"\u002Fcommonhealth\u002F2020\u002F12\u002F23\u002Fmassachusetts-vaccine-delivery-phases-safety-faq","apiURL":"http:\u002F\u002Fapi.wbur.org\u002Fstories?date=2020-12-23&slug=massachusetts-vaccine-delivery-phases-safety-faq&sources=commonhealth","externalURL":"","shortLink":"https:\u002F\u002Fwbur.fm\u002F2LVPtaI","miniExcerpt":"","excerpt":"Massachusetts and most states are offering vaccinations in phases, starting with people most needed to care for the sick and those considered most at risk for severe illness or death. Here's what you should know.","bylines":[{"name":"Martha Bebinger","nameLastFirst":"Bebinger, Martha","slug":"martha-bebinger","wordpressID":842,"content":["Martha Bebinger covers health care and other general assignments for WBUR."],"apiURL":"http:\u002F\u002Fapi.wbur.org\u002Fpeople\u002Fmartha-bebinger","relativeURL":"\u002Finside\u002Fstaff\u002Fmartha-bebinger","organization":"wbur","embedMeta":null,"shortBio":"Martha Bebinger covers health care and other general assignments for WBUR. ","twitter":"mbebinger","facebook":null,"title":"Reporter","type":"newsroom","channels":["news"],"photo":"https:\u002F\u002Fd279m997dpfwgl.cloudfront.net\u002Fwp\u002F2011\u002F06\u002Fmartha_bebinger_square.jpg","website":null,"email":"marthab@bu.edu"}],"nprID":null,"nprTranscriptID":null,"nprURL":null,"dateline":"","superTitle":"Coronavirus Coverage","superTitleURL":"\u002Fcoronavirus","content":["\u003Ch2\u003EMass. Vaccination In Charts\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E","\u003Cspan data-breakout=\"true\" data-index=\"1\" data-type=\"flourish\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","\u003Cspan data-breakout=\"true\" data-index=\"2\" data-type=\"flourish\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","____","\u003Ch2\u003EThe Latest\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E","\u003Cem\u003ETraducido en español \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Felplaneta.com\u002Fnews\u002F2020\u002Fdec\u002F27\u002Flo-que-se-sabe-sobre-la-distribucion-de-la-vacuna-\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003Epor El Planeta\u003C\u002Fa\u003E \u003C\u002Fem\u003E","Just about everyone in Massachusetts now knows when they will be eligible for a coronavirus vaccine. (That's except for children age 15 or younger.)","Here are the dates for remaining priority groups and the general public.","\u003Cul\u003E \t\u003Cli\u003EOn March 22, residents 60 and older and many essential workers will be allowed to book appointments. \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.mass.gov\u002Finfo-details\u002Fcovid-19-vaccinations-for-certain-workers\"\u003EHere are details on which industry workers qualify in this group\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fli\u003E \t\u003Cli\u003EOn April 5, individuals 55 or older, and those with one medical condition that puts them at greater risk of a serious case of COVID-19 become eligible. The state may add more medical conditions to this list by April 5.\u003C\u002Fli\u003E \t\u003Cli\u003EOn April 19, Patriots’ Day, appointments open for all residents age 16 or older.\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\u003C\u002Ful\u003E","\u003Cspan data-index=\"3\" data-type=\"caption\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","Residents can \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.mass.gov\u002Fcovid-19-vaccine?n\"\u003Epreregister\u003C\u002Fa\u003E for appointments at the state's seven mass vaccination sites now. Gov. Charlie Baker says three factors will determine when you are notified by the state's system that you can book an appointment: your eligibility, when you sign up and how quickly slots open near you.","The state has set aside four days -- March 27, April 3, April 10 and April 11 &mdash; at its mega vaccination sites for K-12 teachers, school staff and child care workers.","Baker estimates roughly four million residents who want to be vaccinated will be offered appointments by July 4, but he has urged patience. Keep in mind that President Biden says \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wbur.org\u002Fnpr\u002F973030394\u002Fbiden-says-u-s-will-have-vaccine-supply-for-all-adults-by-may-prioritizes-teache\"\u003Ethere will be enough vaccines\u003C\u002Fa\u003E for all Americans age 16 and older, but not until \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.npr.org\u002Fsections\u002Fcoronavirus-live-updates\u002F2021\u002F03\u002F02\u002F973030394\u002Fbiden-says-u-s-will-have-vaccine-supply-for-all-adults-by-may-prioritizes-teache\"\u003Ethe end of May\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.","This week, the state expects to receive 170,000 new doses, well short of demand from earlier eligibility groups and the roughly 400,000 \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wbur.org\u002Fcommonhealth\u002F2021\u002F03\u002F03\u002Fbaker-vaccine-announcement-schools-teachers\"\u003Eeducators\u003C\u002Fa\u003E to whom the state began offering appointments last week. Baker says the latest word from Washington is that, starting next week, states can expect “hundreds of thousands” more doses per week.","Here’s more on the vaccine rollout in Massachusetts. (This post will be updated as new distribution details emerge.)","____","\u003Ch2\u003EVaccine Rollout Overview\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E","Massachusetts is offering coronavirus vaccinations \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wbur.org\u002Fcommonhealth\u002F2020\u002F12\u002F09\u002Fmassachusetts-vaccine-rollout-plan\"\u003Ein three phases\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, prioritizing people needed to care for the sick, those considered most at risk for severe illness or death and residents in coronavirus hotspot communities.","Virtually all states began with the same top priorities: health care workers and nursing home residents. From there, many states added older residents, aged 65 and up.","Not Massachusetts. In phase one, it vaccinated many of what Baker called hard to reach, vulnerable groups before all seniors, such as shelter residents and prisoners.","Phase two began with residents age 75 and older. Friends and family members who bring them to an appointment can also be \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wbur.org\u002Fcommonhealth\u002F2021\u002F02\u002F10\u002Fcoronavirus-vaccine-massachusetts-accompanying-seniors\"\u003Evaccinated at some clinics\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, including the state's \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wbur.org\u002Fcommonhealth\u002F2021\u002F02\u002F22\u002Ftwo-more-mass-vaccination-sites\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003Emass vaccination sites\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and community health centers.","In February and March, the state expanded eligibility to include educators, residents 65 and older; \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.mass.gov\u002Finfo-details\u002Fcovid-19-vaccinations-for-senior-housing-settings\"\u003Eresidents and staff\u003C\u002Fa\u003E of low-income senior housing; and people who have at least \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.mass.gov\u002Finfo-details\u002Fcovid-19-vaccinations-for-individuals-with-certain-medical-conditions\"\u003Etwo health conditions\u003C\u002Fa\u003E that put them at increased risk for severe COVID-19. There are about 1.5 million people in this group.","Public health experts say it’s not likely that Massachusetts will reach herd immunity until vaccines are available for children 15 and younger. Trials involving children are underway but authorized doses are not expected until later this year or early in 2022.","In phases two and three, Massachusetts has pledged to send 20% more vaccines to communities with the highest infection rates. The Baker administration is also directing \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.mass.gov\u002Fnews\u002Fbaker-polito-administration-announces-vaccine-timeline-for-all-residents-provides-weekly-dose-updates-274-million-in-federal-funding-for-vaccine-equity-initiative\"\u003Efederal dollars\u003C\u002Fa\u003E to the 20 hardest hit communities for outreach, staffing and other administration costs.","____","\u003Cimg class=\"alignnone wp-image-668660 size-full\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fd279m997dpfwgl.cloudfront.net\u002Fwp\u002F2020\u002F12\u002FEwr0PwtWQAcFo23.jpeg\" alt=\"A timeline of rolling out COVID-19 vaccines in Massachusetts. (Courtesy Mass.gov)\" width=\"1251\" height=\"699\" \u002F\u003E","\u003Cspan data-index=\"4\" data-type=\"inset\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","\u003Ch2\u003EVaccine Rollout FAQ\u003C\u002Fh2\u003E","\u003Cstrong\u003EHow do I sign up for a vaccine? \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E","You must make an appointment and register in advance. If \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fvaccinesignup.mass.gov\u002F#\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003Eyou preregister\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, you’ll be notified when an appointment is available near you and will have 24 hours to take it.","If you want to search yourself, here’s the \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.google.com\u002Fmaps\u002Fd\u002Fviewer?mid=1z197EsKQBJ1jkUL9YjnLSRN30qFRnfqd&amp;ll=42.032618861479854%2C-71.62593849999999&amp;z=8\"\u003Emap of public vaccination sites\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.","Community health centers are booking appointments for their patients and the public in areas they serve, \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wbur.org\u002Fcommonhealth\u002F2021\u002F02\u002F24\u002Fsome-hospitals-resuming-new-covid-19-vaccinations-as-supply-increases\"\u003Eas are some hospitals\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. Not all of the sites run by hospitals and community health centers are on the public map.","Health officials ask that you do not sign up at more than one place. Seniors who need help can call 2-1-1. Many senior centers are calling local residents to help them sign up.","\u003Cstrong\u003EWhere will I get the vaccine?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E","The state has more than 200 \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.google.com\u002Fmaps\u002Fd\u002Fviewer?mid=1z197EsKQBJ1jkUL9YjnLSRN30qFRnfqd&amp;ll=42.032618861479854%2C-71.62593849999999&amp;z=8\"\u003Epublic vaccination clinics\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, including seven mega sites at Gillette Stadium, the Hynes Convention Center, the Reggie Lewis Center in Roxbury, the Double Tree Hilton Hotel in Danvers, the Eastfield Mall in Springfield, the Natick Mall and a former Circuit City in Dartmouth. Some cities and towns have regional clinics. Smaller sites include standalone pharmacies and those inside grocery stores, schools, municipal buildings, churches and physician offices.","Thirteen\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wbur.org\u002Fcommonhealth\u002F2021\u002F02\u002F24\u002Fsome-hospitals-resuming-new-covid-19-vaccinations-as-supply-increases\"\u003E hospitals\u003C\u002Fa\u003E have public vaccination clinics. The state’s two largest hospital networks, Mass General Brigham and Beth Israel Lahey Health, are vaccinating their patients, so if you have been treated within these facilities you may be offered an appointment there.","\u003Cstrong\u003EDo I have to prove that I’m eligible?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E","Vaccination sites may ask for an ID. Residents in a priority group such as home care workers, patients with two or more high-risk conditions and teachers are asked to sign this \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.mass.gov\u002Fforms\u002Fcovid-19-massachusetts-vaccination-attestation-form?auHash=Pn6ywcUQKnuzvZPKvVgiw0ldcSPurYBzN8wK6Px7ASs\"\u003Eform,\u003C\u002Fa\u003E confirming they are eligible. People with serious health conditions may want to talk to their doctors to decide \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wbur.org\u002Fcommonhealth\u002F2021\u002F02\u002F18\u002Fcovid-vaccine-phase-two-medical-criteria-uncertainty\"\u003Eif their health conditions qualify\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.","You will likely be asked to show your insurance card, if you have one, when you arrive at the vaccination site or when you sign up because the sites will bill your insurer for the cost of administering the vaccine.","\u003Cstrong\u003EWhat happens at the vaccination clinics?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E","You will be screened for the coronavirus. If you don't have symptoms, and you haven’t been in close contact with anyone who is positive, you may be asked for your identification or confirmation of your appointment before you proceed.","You’ll get the shot.","You’ll be observed in a waiting area for 15 minutes in case you have a rare, immediate adverse reaction, or 30 minutes if you have a history of allergic reactions.","You’ll leave with a card or certificate that indicates which vaccine you received, when and where. Take a picture of this card or make a copy of it. You will be asked for the card when it’s time for your second dose. And you may need the card to prove you’ve been vaccinated if the shots are required by employers or airlines, for example, at some point.","\u003Cspan data-index=\"5\" data-type=\"caption\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","\u003Cstrong\u003EHow will I know when to return for a required second dose, if needed?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E","Try to book your second dose appointment before you leave the site where you received the first dose. If you forget or something goes wrong with the booking, contact the site to let them know you need an appointment for a second dose. ","\u003Cstrong\u003EWill I be able to choose which vaccine I get?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E","You may be able to shop for your choice of vaccine. Many of the vaccination sites list the vaccine that they offer. Experts say take whichever vaccine you are offered. The first two available vaccines, from Pfizer and Moderna, are similarly effective. Johnson &amp; Johnson has been tested against more of the variants and is highly effective in \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.npr.org\u002Fsections\u002Fcoronavirus-live-updates\u002F2021\u002F02\u002F24\u002F970782029\u002Ffda-analysis-of-johnson-johnson-covid-19-vaccine-finds-it-safe-effective\"\u003Epreventing serious illness and death\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.","\u003Cstrong\u003EHow will people be monitored for side effects?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E","The CDC has created an app called V-Safe where you can post information about mild side effects. Someone from the CDC may call you to discuss your reactions. If the headache, fever, nausea or chills persist, you should call your doctor or the vaccination clinic. (The app will also send reminders about a second vaccine dose, if needed.)","More serious side effects should be reported to the federal \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fvaers.hhs.gov\u002Freportevent.html\"\u003EVaccine Adverse Event Reporting System\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.","\u003Cspan data-breakout=\"true\" data-index=\"6\" data-type=\"flourish\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","\u003Cstrong\u003ECan I still get infected after I’ve been vaccinated?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E","Researchers say, maybe. The Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccine trials looked at whether the shots protected recipients against developing the disease, COVID-19, not whether the vaccines prevent transmission of the virus. So you may still become infected and spread the virus even after you’ve been vaccinated. And some of the vaccines \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wbur.org\u002Fnpr\u002F971345409\u002Fcovid-19-vaccine-makers-booster-shots-aim-at-a-moving-target-coronavirus-variant\"\u003Eprotect against some of the variants\u003C\u002Fa\u003E better than others. The bottom line for now: You’ll still have to wear a mask and keep a safe physical distance in public even after you’ve been vaccinated.","\u003Cstrong\u003EHow much will I be charged for a vaccine?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E","Your tax dollars are paying for the vaccines. The Baker administration says vaccine providers will not be allowed to turn anyone away and that health insurers have agreed not to charge members for the cost of administering vaccines — that means no fees, co-payments, co-insurance or payments toward your deductible.","\u003Cstrong\u003EAre the vaccines mandatory?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E","The vaccines will not be mandatory at first. In the future, \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.eeoc.gov\u002Fwysk\u002Fwhat-you-should-know-about-covid-19-and-ada-rehabilitation-act-and-other-eeo-laws\"\u003Eemployers\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, schools and government bodies may require vaccinations.","\u003Cstrong\u003EHow can I learn more about vaccine safety?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E","For more about side effects, what to do if you're pregnant, and what you need to think about before you visit someone who has only received a first dose, read this \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.npr.org\u002Fsections\u002Fhealth-shots\u002F2020\u002F12\u002F12\u002F945288710\u002Fwhat-you-need-to-know-as-the-first-covid-19-vaccine-heads-your-way\"\u003Evaccine FAQ\u003C\u002Fa\u003E from NPR.","\u003Cstrong\u003EWhy did the state start with health care workers and nursing homes?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E","Massachusetts like most states began with health care workers to protect the staff caring for COVID patients. Staff and residents of long-term care facilities are at the top of the list because they are especially vulnerable to infection, serious illness and death from the coronavirus. As of late January, \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.mass.gov\u002Finfo-details\u002Fcovid-19-response-reporting\"\u003Emore than half\u003C\u002Fa\u003E of all COVID deaths in Massachusetts have been long-term care residents.","Hospitals began vaccinating staff on Dec. 14. Eligible employees included doctors, nurses, respiratory therapists and lab technicians in direct contact with COVID-19 patients, as well as people who disinfect rooms. Vaccinations for front-line staff at community health centers, coronavirus testing sites and vaccinators followed. CVS and Walgreens began vaccinating the staff and residents of nursing homes, assisted living facilities and rest homes on Dec. 28.","\u003Cstrong\u003EHere are more details for phase one, which has six subgroups. \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E","The first \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wbur.org\u002Fcommonhealth\u002F2020\u002F12\u002F14\u002Ffirst-coronavirus-vaccines-arrive-in-mass\"\u003Efront-line health care workers\u003C\u002Fa\u003E began receiving the Pfizer vaccine in mid-December. Long-term care residents and staff \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wbur.org\u002Fnews\u002F2020\u002F12\u002F29\u002Fvaccine-nursing-homes-cautious-normal\"\u003Efollowed\u003C\u002Fa\u003E in late December. Clinics for the third group, \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wbur.org\u002Fcommonhealth\u002F2021\u002F01\u002F11\u002Fmassachusetts-begins-vaccines-first-responders\"\u003Efirst responders\u003C\u002Fa\u003E (including police, fire and EMTs), opened on Jan. 11.","People who live in large group settings (like prisons, homeless shelters, addiction treatment centers and group homes) are the fourth priority group in phase one. Home care workers and health care workers who do not deal directly with COVID patients, such as dentists, blood and organ donation employees and behavioral health providers are the final residents eligible in phase one. Everyone in phase one became eligible for the vaccine as of Jan. 21, 2021.","\u003Cspan data-index=\"7\" data-type=\"caption\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","\u003Ca id=\"nl-form-coronavirus\" href=\"#signup\"\u003ESign up\u003C\u002Fa\u003E"],"enhanced":false,"seriesMeta":null,"iframeHero":null,"postType":"post","isBreaking":false,"isDeveloping":false,"relatedLinks":[{"id":197124,"url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wbur.org\u002Fcommonhealth\u002F2020\u002F12\u002F15\u002Fits-definitely-a-relief-massachusetts-health-care-workers-are-now-receiving-a-coronavirus-vaccine","prefix":"","title":"'It's Definitely A Relief': Mass. Health Care Workers Begin Receiving Coronavirus Vaccine","index":1},{"id":197125,"url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wbur.org\u002Fcommonhealth\u002F2020\u002F12\u002F08\u002Fmassinc-polling-coronavirus-vaccine-trust-poll","prefix":"","title":"Poll: Most Mass. Residents Willing To Take Vaccine, But Trust Is Lower Among Black, Latino 09:02:09","updated_at":"2021-03-21 16:00:03","channel":"wbur","title":"More Headlines","url":"","linkTitle":"","contentLimit":8,"index":5,"endsWith":"","allowDupes":false,"icons":false,"locked":false,"display":[],"query":{"org":"wbur"},"meta":{},"dateDisplay":"publish","adType":"billboard","cards":[],"component":{"id":24,"created_at":"2017-05-15 10:34:13","updated_at":"2017-05-15 10:34:13","minimumItems":6,"maximumItems":8,"itemMultiplier":2,"isContentTarget":true,"title":"WallOfLinks","type":"stories","supportsAd":false,"supportsRelLinks":false,"supportsSectionBar":true,"requiresImage":false,"fullContent":false},"contentItems":[{"guid":"e82651a8-cf75-42e1-8448-cb8446106307","id":669134,"channel":"Earthwhile","fullChannel":null,"channelType":"section","program":null,"channelURL":"\u002Fearthwhile","wordpressSlug":"weymouth-compressor-ferc-precedent-enbridge-natural-gas","wordpressID":669134,"source":"earthwhile","headline":"Why A Federal Order In The Weymouth Compressor Case Has The Natural Gas World Worried","subhead":null,"publishDate":"2021-03-19 17:11:47","updatedDate":"2021-03-19 17:58:04","relativeURL":"\u002Fearthwhile\u002F2021\u002F03\u002F19\u002Fweymouth-compressor-ferc-precedent-enbridge-natural-gas","apiURL":"http:\u002F\u002Fapi.wbur.org\u002Fstories?date=2021-03-19&slug=weymouth-compressor-ferc-precedent-enbridge-natural-gas&sources=earthwhile","externalURL":"","shortLink":"https:\u002F\u002Fwbur.fm\u002F3rYJPEZ","miniExcerpt":"","excerpt":"As FERC weighs an unusual review of the Weymouth Compressor, the gas industry worries what this could mean for the fate of other projects.","bylines":[{"name":"Miriam Wasser","nameLastFirst":"Wasser, Miriam","slug":"miriam-wasser","wordpressID":434433,"content":["Miriam Wasser is a reporter for WBUR's environmental vertical, EarthWhile.","Before coming to WBUR, she was a staff writer for the Phoenix New Times in Arizona. Her work has also appeared in Boston Magazine, The Atlantic, Narratively, DigBoston and The Big Roundtable.","Miriam holds a master’s degree from Columbia University’s Graduate School of Journalism, and a BA in government and international relations from Connecticut College.","She once wrote an 11,000-word story about the quirky &mdash; and sometimes dark &mdash; world of domestic rabbit breeding. Really."],"apiURL":"http:\u002F\u002Fapi.wbur.org\u002Fpeople\u002Fmiriam-wasser","relativeURL":"\u002Finside\u002Fstaff\u002Fmiriam-wasser","organization":"wbur","embedMeta":null,"shortBio":"Miriam Wasser is a reporter for WBUR's environmental vertical.","twitter":"@MiriamWasser","facebook":null,"title":"Reporter, EarthWhile","type":"newsroom","channels":["earthwhile","news"],"photo":"https:\u002F\u002Fd279m997dpfwgl.cloudfront.net\u002Fwp\u002F2018\u002F12\u002F0614_wasser-sq01-600x600.jpg","website":null,"email":"mrwasser@bu.edu"}],"nprID":null,"nprTranscriptID":null,"nprURL":null,"dateline":"","superTitle":null,"superTitleURL":null,"content":["In the six years since Massachusetts residents began fighting a proposed natural gas compressor station in Weymouth, the \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wbur.org\u002Fearthwhile\u002F2020\u002F10\u002F13\u002Fweymouth-compressor-explainer-climate-change-enbridge-natural-gas-fracking\"\u003Econtroversial\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wbur.org\u002Fearthwhile\u002F2021\u002F01\u002F22\u002Fenbridge-weymouth-compressor-phmsa-startup\"\u003Enow-operational\u003C\u002Fa\u003E project has mostly been an issue of local concern. Not anymore.","As a challenge to the compressor station’s permit to operate winds its way through the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) &mdash; the agency in charge of approving interstate energy projects &mdash; some on the five-person body have signaled that they’re no longer interested in doing business as usual.","In a 3-2 vote last month, the commission began what some FERC experts are calling “a seemingly unprecedented” review process that not only raises questions about the future of the Weymouth Compressor, but has many in the gas industry worried about the fate of their current and future projects.","At the simplest level, this case is about whether FERC should hold a hearing to relitigate the Weymouth Compressor’s license to operate, known as a “service authorization order.” This happens all the time when project opponents appeal a FERC decision.","But two things make this situation unique: the potential precedent it could set, and the fact that FERC has a new commissioner who has promised to give more weight to climate change and environmental justice concerns.","\u003Cstrong\u003EWhat Is The Weymouth Compressor?\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E","A compressor station is a facility that adds pressure to a gas pipeline system to give the gas a little boost and help it move long distances. Think of it like squeezing a tube of toothpaste; you apply pressure and the toothpaste shoots out.","Natural gas pipelines usually have compressor stations about every 50-100 miles, and there are about 1,700 of them nationwide.","The Weymouth Compressor was designed to be the linchpin of a large interstate gas pipeline system called the Atlantic Bridge Project. The project connects two pipelines and allows fracked natural gas from western Pennsylvania to flow through New Jersey and New England, and into Maine and eastern Canada for local distribution.","\u003Cspan data-index=\"1\" data-type=\"caption\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","Though no public opinion polling about the compressor exists, there is intense opposition to it here in Massachusetts. From activists groups like the \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nocompressor.com\u002F\"\u003EFore River Residents Against the Compressor\u003C\u002Fa\u003E (FRRACS) and Mothers Out Front, to elected officials, the anti-compressor movement here is vocal and visible.","The opposition tends to focus on four issues:","\u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Cem\u003EPublic health and safety:\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E Though rare, compressor stations occasionally catch fire and explode. For this reason, most are built in rural places. The Weymouth Compressor, however, is in a densely populated area that’s prone to flooding and near a busy highway. The site itself is near schools, senior housing and a mental health facility.","Safety concerns about the compressor increased after \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wbur.org\u002Fearthwhile\u002F2020\u002F09\u002F30\u002Fweymouth-compressor-second-unplanned-gas-release\"\u003Etwo unplanned shutdowns\u003C\u002Fa\u003E in September triggered a federal \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wbur.org\u002Fearthwhile\u002F2020\u002F10\u002F01\u002Fphmsa-investigating-weymouth-compressor-gas-releases\"\u003Einvestigation\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.","\u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Cem\u003EEnvironmental justice:\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E Weymouth has \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wbur.org\u002Fearthwhile\u002F2019\u002F12\u002F06\u002Fweymouth-compressor-contamination-cleanup\"\u003Ea long history\u003C\u002Fa\u003E of air pollution and soil contamination. The compressor site is near two state-designated “environmental justice” communities, not to mention a gas-fired power plant, a chemical plant, a sewage pelletizing plant, a gas metering station and the highly trafficked Fore River Bridge.","Residents in the area have statistically higher rates of cancer, pediatric asthma and cardiovascular and respiratory diseases, and \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fd279m997dpfwgl.cloudfront.net\u002Fwp\u002F2019\u002F02\u002FGB-PSR-Report-on-Health-Risks-of-Proposed-Weymouth-Compressor-Station_Feb-7-2019.pdf?fbclid=IwAR1o4TS-aU8OkCU7WeNx6vFFu9e-Qe19AUYlRN6_Ff4aYxvO6ln0JNUSt4Y\"\u003Eaccording to\u003C\u002Fa\u003E the Greater Boston Physicians for Social Responsibility, the “compressor station is, even by data provided by the company itself, likely to worsen the health and safety at this already at-risk community.”","\u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Cem\u003EClimate change:\u003C\u002Fem\u003E \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003EBetween growing evidence that natural gas pipelines emit a lot of the potent greenhouse gas methane, and the fact that the compressor station will periodically release gas and other volatile organic compounds during “blowdowns,” many environmentalists worry about the project’s climate impacts.","They also argue we shouldn’t be building new pipeline infrastructure at a time when scientists warn that we need to reduce our reliance on fossil fuels.","\u003Cem\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EWhether the project is needed:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fem\u003E When the compressor was first proposed, the developer said it had customers lined up to buy the gas. In the years since, that picture \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wbur.org\u002Fearthwhile\u002F2019\u002F11\u002F05\u002Fweymouth-compressor-natural-gas-pipeline-demand\"\u003Ehas changed\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. Enbridge, the company that now owns and operates the Weymouth Compressor, says it currently \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fd279m997dpfwgl.cloudfront.net\u002Fwp\u002F2021\u002F03\u002FAtlantic-Bridge-Customer-Declarations.pdf\"\u003Ehas contracts\u003C\u002Fa\u003E with six gas distribution companies in Maine and Canada, though it declined to say how much gas each receives. Anti-compressor activists are skeptical about the actual demand, and maintain there are enough questions to warrant another look from federal regulators.","\u003Cem\u003E(For a deeper look at who opposes the project and why, check out \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wbur.org\u002Fearthwhile\u002F2020\u002F10\u002F13\u002Fweymouth-compressor-explainer-climate-change-enbridge-natural-gas-fracking\"\u003Eour explainer\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.)\u003C\u002Fem\u003E","\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fd279m997dpfwgl.cloudfront.net\u002Fwp\u002F2021\u002F03\u002Ftimeline.jpg\"\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-669361\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fd279m997dpfwgl.cloudfront.net\u002Fwp\u002F2021\u002F03\u002Ftimeline.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"700\" height=\"2319\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E","\u003Cstrong\u003EFERC Debates The Weymouth Compressor\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E","In January, during its monthly public meeting, FERC discussed whether to officially deny the opponents’ request to “rehear” the authorization order that allowed the compressor to start up.","Three commissioners &mdash; Richard Glick, Allison Clements and Neil Chatterjee &mdash; noted that the project brings up serious environmental justice, health and safety concerns, and said they would vote “no” on the motion to deny the rehearing.","That’s a lot of negatives, we know. But the important thing to note is that three out of the five commissioners signaled that they have serious questions about the Weymouth Compressor and could be willing to take another look at it. (There was no vote on whether to actually schedule a hearing, though.)","After the meeting, Glick took to Twitter: “The Weymouth Compressor Station raises serious environmental justice questions, which we need to examine. The communities surrounding the project are regularly subjected to high levels of pollution &amp; residents are concerned emissions from the station will make things worse … In 3 years at FERC I’ve seen little more than lip service paid to environmental justice. That needs to change.”","\u003Cspan data-index=\"2\" data-type=\"twitter\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","The tweet left the compressor's opponents optimistic, a feeling that increased after President Biden \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.ferc.gov\u002Fnews-events\u002Fnews\u002Fpresident-biden-names-glick-chairman-ferc\"\u003Emade Glick\u003C\u002Fa\u003E the FERC chairman on Jan. 21.","Their excitement, however, did not last long. A day later, the federal government concluded its investigation into the September shutdowns and told Enbridge it \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wbur.org\u002Fearthwhile\u002F2021\u002F01\u002F22\u002Fenbridge-weymouth-compressor-phmsa-startup\"\u003Ecould start up the compressor\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. The facility was in service by the end of the week.","At its February meeting, FERC once again took up the Weymouth Compressor. The commissioners discussed a proposal to establish a comment period known as “\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.ferc.gov\u002Fnews-events\u002Fnews\u002Fferc-establishes-paper-briefing-examine-weymouth-compressor-station-concerns\"\u003Ea paper briefing process.\u003C\u002Fa\u003E”","The goal was to get answers to five questions:","\u003Cul class=\"spaced\"\u003E \t\u003Cli\u003EIs it consistent with FERC’s Natural Gas Act responsibilities to allow the Weymouth Compressor Station to enter and remain in service?\u003C\u002Fli\u003E \t\u003Cli\u003EShould changes in the station’s projected air emissions impacts or public safety impacts cause the Commission to reexamine the project?\u003C\u002Fli\u003E \t\u003Cli\u003EHow might these changes affect the surrounding communities, including environmental justice communities?\u003C\u002Fli\u003E \t\u003Cli\u003EShould FERC impose any additional mitigation measures in response to concerns that have been raised?\u003C\u002Fli\u003E \t\u003Cli\u003EWhat would the consequences be if FERC were to stay or reverse the September 2020 authorization order?\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\u003C\u002Ful\u003E","\u003Cspan data-index=\"3\" data-type=\"caption\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","\u003Cstrong\u003EWhy This Paper Briefing Process Matters\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E","While a paper briefing process itself is not significant or uncommon, FERC doesn’t usually hold one in a situation like this. Gillian Giannetti, a senior lawyer with the watchdog group \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fsustainableferc.org\u002Fabout-the-project\u002F\"\u003EThe Sustainable FERC Project\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, says she can’t think of a time when commissioners have signaled as strongly that they’re willing &mdash; if not outright interested &mdash; in reexamining a project that was already in service.","“I think FERC is taking the position that it's important to take a stand and show that it is an agency that listens and cares about people's concerns,” she says.","The paper briefing process also triggered a striking response. Since the last FERC meeting more than 60 organizations, companies, interest groups and individuals \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Felibrary.ferc.gov\u002FeLibrary\u002Fsearch\"\u003Ehave filed motions\u003C\u002Fa\u003E to become “intervenors” &mdash; essentially, legal participants in the proceeding. (The Sustainable FERC Project is one of them.)","The outcome of the briefing period remains unclear; FERC could vote to hold a hearing, or it could decide to take no action and let the compressor continue operating. But what is clear is that this uncertainty makes the situation more fraught.","Those in the gas industry, as well as those concerned about fossil fuel infrastructure, are left wondering about not only the future of the Weymouth Compressor, but also the fate of all other gas and pipeline projects.","“It seemed like the process was done. It seemed like it had all the approvals from [FERC] that it needed and those were final,” says \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.smu.edu\u002FLaw\u002FFaculty\u002FProfiles\u002FColeman-James-W\"\u003EJames Coleman\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, a FERC expert and law professor at Southern Methodist University. And so for FERC to potentially revisit it “is a big issue for really anybody interested in building energy infrastructure around the United States.”","Giannetti, of the Sustainable FERC Projects, agrees. Imagine you were a gas company with “a project that is built, in service and has a FERC certificate that's 4 years old, and then something happens at one of your compressor stations &mdash; some safety issue,” she says. “There's a concern that this is an attempt to reopen and relitigate FERC authorizations that happened in a different FERC, in a different era.”","\u003Cspan data-index=\"4\" data-type=\"caption\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","\u003Cstrong\u003EThe Dissenting Commissioners\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E","Two FERC commissioners &mdash; James Danly and Mark Christie &mdash; voted against the paper briefing process. In public comments and written dissents, they argued that it was illegal and bad policy.","“Intended or not, the message from this order is clear: even if a pipeline has its certificate, a court upholds that certificate, and that pipeline is in compliance, the Commission can now find a way to modify, or even possibly revoke, the certificate,\" Danly wrote.","Christie made a similar argument: “The majority’s order unquestionably raises the specter of shutting down this completed and functioning project even permanently,” he wrote. “Today’s capricious action violates the most basic standards of regulatory due process and regulatory finality, both of which are absolutely necessary.”","Both men said they believe the briefing process violates the Natural Gas Act and their congressionally approved authority. And at the February meeting, Danly put a finer point on what he sees as the big picture.","“This order by its plain terms casts doubt on every certificate that is held by every natural gas company across the country,\" he said. \"It threatens the finality of orders we issue.\"","Danly encouraged Enbridge to appeal the decision and suggested gas companies get involved. Motions to intervene began appearing in the federal docket a few days later. (Enbridge filed its \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fd279m997dpfwgl.cloudfront.net\u002Fwp\u002F2021\u002F03\u002F20210319-5233_Algonquin-Rehearing-Request-of-Briefing-Order.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"\u003Eappeal\u003C\u002Fa\u003E Friday evening, after publication of this story.)","\u003Cspan data-index=\"5\" data-type=\"caption\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","\u003Cstrong\u003EMore Than 60 Intervenors\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E","There’s a wide range of parties \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Felibrary.ferc.gov\u002FeLibrary\u002Fsearch\"\u003Efiling to intervene.\u003C\u002Fa\u003E In the gas world, applicants include the Maine Public Utilities Commission, which holds contracts for gas that goes through the Weymouth Compressor, to major industry groups like the Natural Gas Association of America and The American Gas Association.","The list also features energy giants like Kinder Morgan, which transports about 40% of the natural gas used in the U.S., and the Electric Power Supply Association, which represents companies like BP, Shell and Calpine Energy.","On the environmental advocacy side, there are local groups like 350 Massachusetts for a Better Future, the Conservation Law Foundation and the Pipeline Awareness Network for the Northeast, as well as big national organizations like the Sierra Club and the Natural Resources Defense Council.","A number of South Shore residents and politicians like House Speaker Ronald Mariano, state Sen. Patrick O’Connor and state Rep. James Murphy have filed to intervene, as have academics like public health expert and Boston College professor Philip Landrigan, and Boston University professor and environmental activist Nathan Phillips.","The list goes on and on; other notable parties include Attorney General Maura Healey, the Weymouth School Board, the Town of Braintree and the Unitarian Universalist Mass Action Network.","\u003Cspan data-index=\"6\" data-type=\"caption\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","Some applicants explained why they were intervening in their filing, and WBUR reached out to several more. Here’s some of what we heard:","\u003Cul class=\"spaced\"\u003E \t\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Cem\u003EIroquois Gas Transmission System\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E: “We are concerned that the latest development in this proceeding calls into question the finality of the FERC process, which is a concern to all interstate pipelines who are anticipating making future infrastructure investments.”\u003C\u002Fli\u003E \t\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Cem\u003EEastern Shore Natural Gas Company\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E: \"Prior to the issuance of the February 18, 2021 Order Establishing Briefing, Eastern Shore had no reason to intervene ... However, the Feb. 18 Order requested briefing on topics that extend beyond the immediate project and that could have a causal relationship to Eastern Shore and the natural gas industry as a whole.”\u003C\u002Fli\u003E \t\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Cem\u003ETom Kiley, CEO of Northeast Gas Association\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E: “If FERC were to do [this] then wouldn’t that open up every project of all types, all fuels, to be challenged? Anybody that was opposed to something could have another shot at that.”\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\u003C\u002Ful\u003E","On the other side, intervention applicants said they filed because they see this as a second chance to get their concerns heard, and they hold out hope that FERC will reverse its authorization order.","\u003Cul class=\"spaced\"\u003E \t\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Cem\u003EState Sen. Patrick O'Connor\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E: “The siting of that compressor station in North Weymouth &mdash; the Fore River Basin &mdash; is one of the most irresponsible sitings of energy infrastructure [in the U.S.], in my opinion … I think the government really needs to understand that people aren't going to take rubber stamps anymore.”\u003C\u002Fli\u003E \t\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Cem\u003EPhilip Landrigan, public health expert\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E: “All of these groups are joining together and they're catalyzed by the recognition that a very poor job was done in the health impact assessment several years ago. There's a real opportunity against the background of this incomplete piece of work to overturn the decision.”\u003C\u002Fli\u003E \t\u003Cli\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Cem\u003EDr. Brita Lundberg, Greater Boston Physicians for Social Responsibility\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E: “FERC specifically asked about what safety and environmental justice issues we know about now that we did not know about when the project was approved. … I find it a very hopeful sign that FERC is now offering to listen. … There is still the opportunity to do the right thing.”\u003C\u002Fli\u003E\u003C\u002Ful\u003E","Bottom line, says FERC expert Giannetti, it’s not uncommon for there to be so many parties interested in intervening in high-profile projects. It’s just that, until recently, the Weymouth Compressor did not fall into this category.","While the project has been “extremely contentious on Twitter and extremely contentious in New England, it has largely been a sleeper docket at FERC for a long time,” she says. “And then FERC did something that is very newsworthy, very intriguing. And it’s bringing eyes to this proceeding that would not have otherwise been there.”","“It's sort of [its] Dakota Access Pipeline moment,” Coleman says.","\u003Cstrong\u003EA Changing FERC\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E","There’s one other big factor in the background: the shifting priorities and dynamics within FERC.","By law, FERC can’t have more than three commissioners from the same party. The current makeup includes three Republicans: Danly, Christie and Chatterjee, and two Democrats: Glick and Clements. In June, Chatterjee’s term will be up and Biden will appoint another (likely Democratic, and likely progressive) commissioner.","\u003Cspan data-index=\"7\" data-type=\"caption\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E","Glick, the current chairman, has been outspoken about his belief that FERC needs to give more consideration to the climate change and environmental justice impacts of the projects it reviews. He has also made moves to establish a new \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.ferc.gov\u002Fnews-events\u002Fnews\u002Fferc-announces-workshop-regarding-creation-office-public-participation\"\u003EOffice of Public Participation\u003C\u002Fa\u003E at FERC and announced a new \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.ferc.gov\u002Fnews-events\u002Fnews\u002Fferc-chairman-acts-ensure-prominent-ferc-role-environmental-justice\"\u003Esenior position\u003C\u002Fa\u003E dedicated to environmental justice and equity.","“This position is not just a title,” Glick said in a \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.ferc.gov\u002Fnews-events\u002Fnews\u002Fferc-chairman-acts-ensure-prominent-ferc-role-environmental-justice\"\u003Erecent statement\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. “I intend to do what it takes to empower this new position to ensure that environmental justice and equity concerns finally get the attention they deserve.”","According to Giannetti and Coleman, those recent comments, plus his vote in favor of the briefing process for the Weymouth Compressor, signal Glick’s desire to end FERC’s reputation as a “rubber stamp” for fossil fuel companies.","What’s more, FERC is planning to update its policy statement &mdash; its North Star, so to speak &mdash; which sets guidance for assessing whether a project is needed, safe and in the public interest.","As FERC reevaluates its priorities, the coming appointment of a new member brings even greater expectations for change.","“Do I expect a FERC that has a Democratic majority to be different than the FERC we saw for most of the Trump administration? Absolutely,” Giannetti says. “In terms of what's going to be different, I don't really want to get ahead of the agency. But I can say this much, Commissioner Glick has made it clear that environmental justice is a huge concern of his.”","What exactly this all means for the Weymouth Compressor remains to be seen. But the very real possibility that FERC could decide to take an unprecedented step like revoking or staying the project’s authorization order, has meant that for now, all eyes in the gas world are on the compressor."],"enhanced":false,"seriesMeta":null,"iframeHero":null,"postType":"post","isBreaking":false,"isDeveloping":false,"relatedLinks":[],"relatedLinksLabel":"Related:","broadcastType":"","broadcastDate":"","broadcastTime":"","itunesEpType":"","itunesEpNum":0,"itunesTitle":"","itunesSummary":"","itunesExplicit":false,"volume":3,"disqus":null,"enableComments":false,"googlePick":false,"suppressAudio":false,"amp":true,"audioDatetime":null,"pullquotes":[],"taxonomy":[{"id":67,"type":"category","name":"Environment","description":"","slug":"environment","series":false,"count":5200},{"id":73,"type":"category","name":"News","description":"","slug":"news","series":false,"count":58847},{"id":75,"type":"category","name":"Politics","description":"","slug":"politics","series":false,"count":25527},{"id":200,"type":"tag","name":"WBUR's Morning Edition","description":"Local content from WBUR's Morning Edition broadcasts","slug":"morning-edition","series":false,"count":5085}],"audio":[],"embedMeta":{"embed-1":{"id":1,"parentID":669134,"type":"caption","attributes":{"id":"attachment_631844","align":"aligncenter","width":"1000","caption":"A map of the Atlantic Bridge Project. (Courtesy of FERC.)\" width=\"1000\" height=\"667\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E","placeholder":"\u003Cspan data-index=\"4\" data-type=\"caption\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E"},"embed-5":{"id":5,"parentID":669134,"type":"caption","attributes":{"id":"attachment_669150","align":"aligncenter","width":"1920","caption":"The Weymouth Natural Gas Compressor Station. (Robin Lubbock\u002FWBUR)","alt":""},"body":"\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fd279m997dpfwgl.cloudfront.net\u002Fwp\u002F2021\u002F03\u002FWeymouth-Photo2.jpg\"\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"wp-image-669150 size-breakout\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fd279m997dpfwgl.cloudfront.net\u002Fwp\u002F2021\u002F03\u002FWeymouth-Photo2-1920x1095.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1920\" height=\"1095\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E","placeholder":"\u003Cspan data-index=\"5\" data-type=\"caption\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E"},"embed-6":{"id":6,"parentID":669134,"type":"caption","attributes":{"id":"attachment_533055","align":"aligncenter","width":"1000","caption":"In this 1987 photo, you can see the 11.2 million gallon tank of diesel fuel and a pile of coal on the parcel of land where the Weymouth Compressor now sits (top left).","alt":""},"body":"\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fd279m997dpfwgl.cloudfront.net\u002Fwp\u002F2019\u002F12\u002FFore_River_Shipyard_from_the_west.jpg\"\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"size-large wp-image-533055\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fd279m997dpfwgl.cloudfront.net\u002Fwp\u002F2019\u002F12\u002FFore_River_Shipyard_from_the_west-1000x588.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1000\" height=\"588\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E","placeholder":"\u003Cspan data-index=\"6\" data-type=\"caption\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E"},"embed-7":{"id":7,"parentID":669134,"type":"caption","attributes":{"id":"attachment_669145","align":"alignright","width":"400","caption":"President Biden made Richard Glick Chairman of FERC on Jan. 21, 2021.
